page.title: Chronological summary of the 2014 Winter Olympics

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Zyxw|Zyxw]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}}{{Use British English|date=February 2014}}{{2014 Winter Olympics}} This page contains a '''chronological summary''' of major events from the '''[[2014 Winter Olympics]]''' in [[Sochi]], [[Russia]].
==Calendar== {{2014 Winter Olympics Calendar}}
==Day 0 – Thursday 6 February== Twelve new events were added for the games.<ref name="sportsnew">{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/sport/rogge-sochi2014-new-sports/|publisher=TV-Novosti|work=Russia Today|accessdate=5 January 2013|date=5 July 2011|title=Rogge announces three new disciplines for Sochi 2014}}</ref> For this reason competition started a day before the opening ceremony. This marks the first time in the history of the [[Winter Olympics]] that competitions were held before the opening ceremony.<ref>{{cite news |title=Figure skating-New team event at Sochi Olympics will begin early |first=Pritha |last=Sarkar |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/29/figure-skating-olympics-team-idUSL3E8ET8WL20120329 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=29 March 2012 |accessdate=5 January 2013}}</ref>
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * In the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Team trophy|team trophy]] competition, the men's short and the pairs short were held. The [[Russia at the 2014 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|Russians]] led the day with 19 points, with [[Evgeni Plushenko]]'s nine points in the men's short, and [[Tatiana Volosozhar]] and [[Maxim Trankov]]'s ten points in the pairs short. Japan's [[Yuzuru Hanyu]] earned ten points to finish in first place in the men's short, but [[Narumi Takahashi]] and [[Ryuichi Kihara]] only gained three more points for [[Japan at the 2014 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|Japan]] in the pairs short. [[Canada at the 2014 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|Canada]] and [[China at the 2014 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|China]] finish the day holding the second and third overall positions, respectively.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-men-short-program | title=Figure Skating – Team Men Short Program results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=6 February 2014 | accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-pairs-short-program | title=Figure Skating – Team Pairs Short Program results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=6 February 2014 | accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] *[[Hannah Kearney]] of the United States finished in first place in the first qualifying round of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's moguls|women's moguls]] with a score of 23.05.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-ladies-moguls-qualification-1 | title=Freestyle Skiing – Ladies' Moguls Qualification 1 results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=6 February 2014 | accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref> The top ten move on to the third round, while the remaining 20 move onto Round 2.
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * Canada's [[Maxence Parrot]] led the qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|men's slopestyle]] with a best score of 97.50,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-men-s-sbs-qualification | title=Snowboarding – Men's Slopestyle Qualification results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=6 February 2014 | accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref> while Switzerland's [[Isabel Derungs]] led the qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's slopestyle|women's slopestyle]] with a best score of 87.50.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-ladies-sbs-qualification | title=Snowboarding -Ladies' Slopestyle Qualification results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=6 February 2014 | accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref> The top four in each heat automatically advance to the final, while the remaining athletes progress to the semifinal.
==Day 1 – Friday 7 February== ; [[File:Olympic Rings Icon.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[2014 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|Opening ceremony]]: * The opening ceremony started at 20:14 [[Moscow Time|MSK]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/30/sport/sochi-2014-venues-winter-olympics/|title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympic venues|first=Inez|last=Torre|date=31 October 2013|accessdate=12 December 2013|publisher=CNN}}</ref> at [[Fisht Olympic Stadium]], with an audience of 40,000 in attendance. Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] declared the games officially open, while [[Irina Rodnina]] and [[Vladislav Tretiak]] jointly lit the [[Olympic cauldron]] installed at the [[Sochi Medals Plaza]] in the [[Sochi Olympic Park]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Dassanayake |first=Dion |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/458578/Winter-Olympics-Opening-ceremony-for-Sochi-2014-kicks-off-with-a-bang |title=Winter Olympics: Embarrassing technical hitch hits start of Sochi 2014 opening ceremony |newspaper=[[Daily Express]] |date=7 February 2014 |accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics opens with glittering ceremony |first=Sam |last=Sheringham |publisher=BBC |date=7 February 2014 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/winter-olympics/25885398 |accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref>
==Day 2 – Saturday 8 February== ;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] *[[Ole Einar Bjørndalen]] of Norway won the gold medal in the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's sprint|men's sprint]] with a time of 24:33.5, while [[Dominik Landertinger]] of Austria recorded a time of 24:34.8 to win the silver and [[Jaroslav Soukup]] of the Czech Republic earned the bronze with a time of 24:39.2.<ref name="Day2-Biathlon-men's sprint">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/biathlon-men-s-10-km-sprint | title=Biathlon – Men's Sprint 10 km results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> Bjørndalen tied the record for most Winter Olympics medals.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/08/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-one-live-report |title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day one – as it happened |date=8 February 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * [[Marit Bjørgen]] of Norway finished the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 15 kilometre skiathlon|women's 15 km skiathlon]] with a time of 38:33.6 to win the gold medal. Sweden's [[Charlotte Kalla]] finished with the silver with a time of 38:35.4, and [[Heidi Weng]] of Norway took the bronze with a time of 38:46.8.<ref name="Day2-Cross-country-women's 15km skiathlon">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/cross-country-ladies-skiathlon-7-5-km-c-7-5-km-f | title=Cross country Skiing – Women's 15 km Skiathlon results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * On the second day of the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Team trophy|team trophy]] competition, [[Meryl Davis]] and [[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]] of the United States led the ice dance short program with 10 points.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-ice-dance-short-dance | title=Figure Skating – Team Ice Dance Short Program results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> In the women's short program, [[Yulia Lipnitskaya]] led all competitors by earning 10 points for Russia.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-ladies-short-program | title=Figure Skating – Team Ladies Short Program results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> [[Ksenia Stolbova]] and [[Fedor Klimov]] also earned 10 points for Russia in the pairs free program.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-pairs-free-skating | title=Figure Skating – Team Pairs Free Skating results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> The five teams that advanced to the final day of competition were Russia (47 points), Canada (41) USA (34), Italy (31) and Japan (30).
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * In the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's moguls|women's moguls]], Russia's [[Ekaterina Stolyarova]] came in first in the second qualifying round to advance to the final along with nine others.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-ladies-moguls-qualification-2 | title=Freestyle Skiing – Ladies' Moguls Qualification 2 results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> Then in final, Canadian sisters [[Justine Dufour-Lapointe|Justine]] and [[Chloé Dufour-Lapointe]] took gold and silver, respectively, while [[Hannah Kearney]] of the United States finished third.<ref name="Day2-Freestyle skiing-Women's moguls">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-ladies-moguls-final-3 | title=Freestyle Skiing – Ladies' Moguls Final 3 results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group A *** '''{{ihw|USA}}''' 3–1 {{ihw|FIN}} *** '''{{ihw|CAN}}''' 5–0 {{ihw|SUI}}
;[[Image:Luge pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The first two runs of the [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] were held.
;[[Image:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * In the qualification round of the [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's normal hill individual|men's normal hill individual]], [[Michael Hayböck]] of Austria led all competitors with a score of 128.6.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/ski-jumping-men-s-normal-hill-ind-qual-round | title=Ski Jumping – Men's Normal Hill Individual Qualification Round results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> He will join 39 others, and 10 jumpers from the [[2013–14 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup]], in the finals.
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|men's slopestyle]], [[Billy Morgan (snowboarder)|Billy Morgan]] (Great Britain), [[Sage Kotsenburg]] (United States), [[Mark McMorris]] (Canada) and [[Yuki Kadono]] (Japan) finished in the top four in the semifinal to qualify for the final.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-men-s-sbs-semifinals | title=Snowboarding – Men's Slopestyle Semifinals results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> Kotsenburg then won the gold in the final with a score of 93.50 on his first run. [[Ståle Sandbech]] (Norway) won the silver with a score of 91.75 and McMorris earned the bronze with 88.75.<ref name="Day2-Snowboarding - Men's Slopestyle">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-men-s-sbs-finals | title=Snowboarding – Men's Finals results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * [[Sven Kramer]] of the Netherlands set an [[World and Olympic records set at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Olympic record]] of 6:10.76 in the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|men's 5000 metres]] to win the gold medal, while fellow Dutch skaters [[Jan Blokhuijsen]] and [[Jorrit Bergsma]] recorded times of 6:15.71 and 6:16.66 to earn the other two medals, respectively.<ref name="Day2-Speed Skating - Men's 5000m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/speed-skating-men-s-5000-m | title=Speed Skating – Men's 5000 m results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=8 February 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="6" | Gold medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's sprint|Men's sprint]] |[[Ole Einar Bjørndalen]] |{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day2-Biathlon-men's sprint" /> |- |[[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] |[[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 15 kilometre skiathlon|Women's 15 km skiathlon]] |[[Marit Bjørgen]] |{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day2-Cross-country-women's 15km skiathlon" /> |- |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's moguls|Women's moguls]] |[[Justine Dufour-Lapointe]] |{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day2-Freestyle skiing-Women's moguls" /> |- |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|Men's slopestyle]] |[[Sage Kotsenburg]] |{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day2-Snowboarding - Men's Slopestyle" /> |- |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|Men's 5000 metres]] |[[Sven Kramer]] |{{flagIOC|NED|2014 Winter}} |[[List of Olympic records in speed skating#Men|OR]] |<ref name="Day2-Speed Skating - Men's 5000m" /> |}
==Day 3 – Sunday 9 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * [[Matthias Mayer]] of Austria won the gold in the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's downhill|men's downhill]] with a time of 2:06.23, beating [[Christof Innerhofer]] of Italy by 0.06 seconds, and [[Kjetil Jansrud]] of Norway by 0.10 seconds.<ref name="Day3-Alpine Skiing-men's downhill">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/alpine-skiing-men-s-downhill | title=Men's Downhill – Alpine Skiing | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/09/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-two-live |title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day two – as it happened |date=9 February 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * In the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's sprint|women's sprint]], [[Anastasiya Kuzmina]] of Slovakia became the first female biathlete to repeat as Olympic champion. Russia's [[Olga Vilukhina]] finished 19.9 seconds behind to win the silver and Ukraine's [[Vita Semerenko]] finished 21.7 seconds behind to win the bronze.<ref name="Day3-Biathlon-women's sprint">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/biathlon-women-s-7-5-km-sprint | title=Women's 7.5 km Sprint – Biathlon | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 30 kilometre skiathlon|men's 30 km skiathlon]], [[Dario Cologna]] of Switzerland took home the gold medal with a total time of 1:08:15.4. [[Marcus Hellner]] of Sweden finished 0.4 seconds behind Cologna to win the silver, and [[Martin Johnsrud Sundby]] of Norway finished 1.4 seconds behind to take the bronze.<ref name="Day3-Cross country-men's 30km skiathlon">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/cross-country-men-s-skiathlon-15-km-c-15-km-f | title=Men's Skiathlon 15 km Classic + 15 km Free – Cross-Country | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * In the third and final day of the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Team trophy|team trophy]] competition, Russia won the gold medal with 75 points, while Canada finished in second with 65 points, and the United States in third with 60 points.<ref name="Day3-Figure Skating-Team">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-teams-standings | title=Figure Skating – Team Standings | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref> For Russia, [[Evgeni Plushenko]] scored ten points in the men's free program, and [[Yulia Lipnitskaya]] had ten points in the women's free program.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-men-free-skating | title=Figure Skating – Team Men Free Program | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-ladies-free-skating | title=Figure Skating – Team Ladies Free Program | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref> [[Meryl Davis]] and [[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]] of the United States led the ice dance free program with 10 points.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-team-ice-dance-free-dance | title=Figure Skating – Team Free Dance Program | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group B *** '''{{ihw|SWE}}''' 1–0 {{ihw|JPN}} *** '''{{ihw|RUS}}''' 4–1 {{ihw|GER}}
[[Image:Luge pictogram.svg|30px]]''' [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]]''' * The two final runs of the [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] were held. Germany's [[Felix Loch]] won the gold, with Russia's [[Albert Demchenko]] winning silver at 0.088 behind, and Italy's [[Armin Zöggeler]] winning bronze at +0.230 behind.<ref name="Day3-Luge-men's singles">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/luge-men-s-singles-run-4 | title=Men's Singles Run 4 – Luge | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * [[Kamil Stoch]] of Poland recorded a total score of 276.7 in the [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's normal hill individual|men's normal hill individual]] to win the gold medal. Slovenian [[Peter Prevc]] finished in second with 265.8, and [[Anders Bardal]] of Norway held third place with 264.1.<ref name="Day3-Ski Jumping-men's normal hill">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/ski-jumping-men-s-normal-hill-ind-final-round | title=Men's Normal Hill Individual Final Round – Ski Jumping | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's slopestyle|women's slopestyle]], [[Šárka Pančochová]] (Czech Republic), [[Sina Candrian]] (Switzerland), [[Jenny Jones (snowboarder)|Jenny Jones]] (Great Britain) and [[Silje Norendal]] (Norway) finished in the top four in the semifinal to qualify for the final.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-ladies-sbs-semifinals | title=Ladies' Slopestyle Semifinals – Snowboard | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref> In the final, [[Jamie Anderson (snowboarder)|Jamie Anderson]] of the United States won gold with a score of 95.25, while [[Enni Rukajärvi]] of Finland finished second with 92.50, and Jones won the bronze medal with 87.25 points.<ref name="Day3-Snowboarding-women's slopestyle">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-ladies-sbs-finals | title=Ladies' Slopestyle Finals – Snowboard | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * [[Ireen Wüst]] of the Netherlands won gold in the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metres|women's 3000 metres]] with a time of 4:00.34. [[Martina Sáblíková]] of the Czech Republic took the silver medal at 1.61 seconds back, and Russia's [[Olga Graf]] came in third place at 3.13 back.<ref name="Day3-Speed skating-women's 3000m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/speed-skating-ladies-3000-m | title=Ladies' 3000 m – Speed Skating | work=Sochi 2014 | date=9 February 2014 | accessdate=9 February 2014}}</ref>

==Day 4 – Monday 10 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] *[[Maria Höfl-Riesch]] of Germany won the gold medal in the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's combined|women's combined]] with a total time of 2:34.62. [[Nicole Hosp]] of Austria finished second at 0.40 seconds back, and [[Julia Mancuso]] of the United States took away the bronze medal at 0.53 seconds back.<ref name="Day4-Alpine Skiing-women's combined">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/alpine-skiing-ladies-super-combined-slalom | title=Alpine Skiing – Ladies Super Combined Slalom | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/10/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-three-live |title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day three – as it happened |date=10 February 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref> Mancuso led the downhill section of the race at 1:42.68, with [[Lara Gut]] of Switzerland in second at 1:43.15 and [[Tina Maze]] of Slovenia in third at 1:43.54.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/alpine-skiing-ladies-super-combined-downhill | title=Alpine Skiing – Women's Super Combined Downhill | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref> [[Šárka Strachová]] of the Czech Republic finished first in the slalom section at 50.10, [[Michaela Kirchgasser]] of Austria in second at 50.69, and [[Maria Höfl-Riesch]] of Germany in third at 50.90.<ref name="Day4-Alpine Skiing-women's combined" />
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * France's [[Martin Fourcade]] won the gold medal in the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's pursuit|men's pursuit]] by a margin of 14.1 seconds. [[Ondřej Moravec]] of the Czech Republic finished second, with no penalties in the whole race. The bronze medal went to France's [[Jean-Guillaume Béatrix]], who finished 24.2 seconds back.<ref name="Day4-Biathlon-men's pursuit">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/biathlon-men-s-12-5-km-pursuit | title=Biathlon – Men's 12.5 km Pursuit | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] *[[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 1 ***{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} 4–7 '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' ***{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} 5–7 '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' ***{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} 4–7 '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' ***{{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} 8–11 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' ** Round robin, draw 2 ***'''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 8–4 {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} ***{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} 4–5 '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' ***{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 4–7 '''{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}}''' ***'''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' 11–10 {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} *[[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 1 ***{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} 2–9 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' ***'''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' 7–4 {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} ***'''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 6–4 {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} ***'''{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}}''' 7–4 {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * In the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's moguls|men's moguls]], [[Alexandre Bilodeau]] and [[Mikaël Kingsbury]] (both Canada), as well as [[Alexandr Smyshlyaev]] (Russia), finished in the top three positions in the first qualifying section, to move on to the quarterfinal with seven other competitors. Those who had not made it through competed again, with [[Patrick Deneen (skier)|Patrick Deneen]] (USA) topping the leaderboard in the second qualifying section. The final consisted of three rounds, with the top 12 of the first round advancing to the second round, and the top six in the second advancing to the third. With a score of 26.31, [[Alexandre Bilodeau]] of Canada won the gold medal, while [[Mikaël Kingsbury]] of Canada won the silver and [[Alexandr Smyshlyaev]] of Russia finishing third, a repeat of the top three positions from the first qualifying round.<ref name="Day4-Freesyle skiing-men's moguls">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-men-s-moguls-final-3 | title=Freestyle Skiing – Men's Moguls Final 3 | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group A *** '''{{ihw|USA}}''' 9–0 {{ihw|SUI}} *** {{ihw|FIN}} 0–3 '''{{ihw|CAN}}'''
;[[Image:Luge pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]] *The first two runs of the [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]] were held. Germany's [[Natalie Geisenberger]] finished with the best time from the first two runs, with another German competitor, [[Tatjana Hüfner]], finishing the day in second position (3rd in run 1, 2nd in run 2). [[Erin Hamlin]] of the United States was the only other competitor to reach the top three in either of the two runs, leaving her in the bronze medal position at the half-way stage of the competition.
;[[Image:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] *In the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|men's 1500 metres]], [[Charles Hamelin]] (Canada) won the gold medal with a time of 2:14.985. [[Han Tianyu]] (China) finished second and [[Viktor Ahn]] (Russia) finished in third place.<ref name="Day4-Short track-men's 1500 m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/short-track-men-s-1500-m-finals | title=Short Track – Men's 1500 m Finals | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref> The competition began with the qualifying heats, in which the three fastest times were posted by [[Niels Kerstholt]] (Netherlands), [[François Hamelin]] (Canada) and [[Thibaut Fauconnet]] (France), in the 5th heat. In the semifinals, the quickest times were from [[Charles Hamelin]] (Canada) and [[Jack Whelbourne]] (Great Britain), in heat 3, both qualifying for Final A (the medal round). In Final B (a classification round) [[Sébastien Lepape]] (France) finished first. *In the qualifying heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|women's 500 metres]], [[Fan Kexin]] (China), [[Jessica Hewitt]] (Canada) and [[Liu Qiuhong]] (China) recorded the three fastest times, and were among the 16 to qualify for the next round of the competition.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/short-track-ladies-500-m-heats | title=Short Track – Ladies' 500 m Heats | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref> * In the semifinals of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metre relay|women's 3000 metre relay]], South Korea and Canada came first and second respectively in the first race, qualifying for the medal final. China and Italy finished in the top two in the second semifinal, also qualifying for the medal final.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/short-track-ladies-500-m-heats | title=Short Track – Ladies' 3000 m Relay Semifinals | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The Netherlands finished with all three medals in the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500 metres]], with [[Michel Mulder]] winning the gold with a combined time of just 0.01 seconds faster than [[Jan Smeekens]]. [[Ronald Mulder]] finished the event 0.15 behind in third place.<ref name="Day4-Speed skating-men's 500 m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/speed-skating-men-s-500-m-race-2-of-2 | title=Speed Skating – Men's 500 m Race 2 of 2 | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="6" | Gold medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |[[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] |[[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's combined|Women's combined]] |[[Maria Höfl-Riesch]] |{{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day4-Alpine Skiing-women's combined" /> |- |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's pursuit|Men's pursuit]] |[[Martin Fourcade]] |{{flagIOC|FRA|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day4-Biathlon-men's pursuit" /> |- |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's moguls|Men's moguls]] |[[Alex Bilodeau]] |{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day4-Freesyle skiing-men's moguls" /> |- |[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] |[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|Men's 1500 metres]] |[[Charles Hamelin]] |{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day4-Short track-men's 1500 m" /> |- |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|Men's 500 metres]] |[[Michel Mulder]] |{{flagIOC|NED|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day4-Speed skating-men's 500 m" /> |}
==Day 5 – Tuesday 11 February== ;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * [[Darya Domracheva]] of Belarus recorded a time of 29:30.7 to win the gold medal in the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's pursuit|women's pursuit]]. [[Tora Berger]] of Norway won the silver at 37.6 seconds back, and [[Teja Gregorin]] of Slovenia captured bronze at 42.0 back.<ref name="Day5-Biathlon-women's pursuit">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/biathlon-women-s-10-km-pursuit | title=Biathlon: Women's 10km Pursuit | work=Sochi 2014 | date=10 February 2014 | accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30x30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * Norway won gold in both the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's sprint|men's sprint]] and the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's sprint|women's sprint]], with performances by [[Ola Vigen Hattestad]] and [[Maiken Caspersen Falla]], respectively. The other two medals in the men's sprint went to Sweden: [[Teodor Peterson]] got the silver and [[Emil Jönsson]] earned the bronze.<ref name="Day5-Cross Country-men's sprint">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-norway-s-ola-vigen-hattestad-takes-the-olympic-gold-in-the-men-s-cross-country-freestyle-sprint | title=Norway's Ola Vigen Hattestad takes the Olympic gold in the men's cross country freestyle sprint | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref> Norway's [[Ingvild Flugstad Østberg]] also claimed silver in the women's event, while [[Vesna Fabjan]] of Slovenia finished in third.<ref name="Day5-Cross Country-women's sprint">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-norway-claimed-gold-and-silver-in-the-ladies-sprint-final | title=Norway claimed gold and silver in the ladies sprint final | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
; [[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 3 *** '''{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}}''' 9–8 {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} 6–7 '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 4–9 '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' 7–6 {{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 2 *** '''{{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}}''' 12–7 {{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}}''' 9–6 {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' 7–6 {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}} 3–9 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' ** Round robin, draw 3 *** {{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}} 6–8 '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' 7–5 {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} 3–8 '''{{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' 12–3 {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} **** Great Britain equalled an Olympic record score with this victory, in which they also scored seven points in one end, something which has never been done before at the Olympics.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/winter-olympics/2613852 Sochi 2014: British women in record-equalling win over USA, ''BBC Sport.'' 11 February 2014. Retrieved 12 February 2014.</ref>
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * In [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Pair skating|pairs skating]], Russia's [[Tatiana Volosozhar]] and [[Maxim Trankov]] set a new world record score in the short program with 84.17 points. Germany's [[Aliona Savchenko]] and [[Robin Szolkowy]] finished in second with 79.64 points, and Russia's [[Ksenia Stolbova]] and [[Fedor Klimov]] held third with 75.21 points.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-tatiana-volosozhar-and-maxim-trankov-new-record-and-hopes-for-gold | title=Tatiana Volosozhar and Maxim Trankov: new record and hopes for gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * Canada's [[Dara Howell]] scored 94.20 points to win the gold medal in the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's slopestyle|women's slopestyle]]. [[Devin Logan]] finished in second with 85.40, barely finishing 0.40 behind Canada's [[Kim Lamarre]], the bronze medal winner.<ref name="Day5-Freestyle skiing-women's slopestyle">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-howell-winner-in-women-s-freestyle-slopestyle | title=Howell – winner in women's slopestyle | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group B *** {{ihw|GER}} 0–4 '''{{ihw|SWE}}''' *** '''{{ihw|RUS}}''' 2–1 {{ihw|JPN}}
;[[Image:Luge pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * Germany's [[Natalie Geisenberger]] won the gold medal in the [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]], finishing 1.139 seconds ahead of second place [[Tatjana Hüfner]] of Germany, the largest margin in an Olympic luge event since the [[1964 Olympic Winter Games|1964 Winter Games]]. [[Erin Hamlin]] of the United States finished with the bronze.<ref name="Day5-Luge-women's singles">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-natalie-geisenberger-wins-by-biggest-winning-margin-since-1964 | title=Natalie Geisenberger wins by biggest winning margin since 1964 | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * The first ever Olympic gold medal in ski jumping went to Germany's [[Carina Vogt]] for the [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's normal hill individual|women's normal hill individual]]. Austria's [[Daniela Iraschko-Stolz]] and France's [[Coline Mattel]] won the silver and bronze, respectively.<ref name="Day5-Ski jumping-women's normal hill">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-carina-vogt-germany-wins-first-women-s-ski-jumping-gold | title=Carina Vogt (Germany) wins first women's ski jumping gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * [[Iouri Podladtchikov]] (Switzerland) captured the gold in the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's halfpipe|men's halfpipe]]. [[Ayumu Hirano]] and [[Taku Hiraoka]] won the silver and the bronze, respectively, becoming the first Olympic snowboarding medalists from an Asian country.<ref name="Day5-Snowboarding-men's halfpipe">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-iouri-podladtchikov-upsets-white-to-win-men-s-halfpipe-gold | title=Podladtchikov upsets White to win men's halfpipe gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
; [[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30x30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * South Korea's [[Lee Sang-hwa]] set Olympic records in the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|women's 500 metres]] with a time of 37.28 in a race, and a combined time of 1:14.70 in two races. She also became the third woman speed skater to win multiple Olympic golds.<ref name="Day5-Speed skating-women's 500m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-lee-sang-hwa-grabbed-gold-in-the-ladies-speed-skating-500m | title=Lee Sang Hwa grabbed gold in the ladies speed skating 500m | work=Sochi 2014 | date=11 February 2014 | accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref> [[Olga Fatkulina]] of Russia finished with the silver and [[Margot Boer]] of the Netherlands earned the bronze.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/11/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-four-live |title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day four – as it happened |date=11 February 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>

==Day 6 – Wednesday 12 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * In the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's downhill|women's downhill]], [[Tina Maze]] of Slovenia and [[Dominique Gisin]] of Switzerland both recorded times of 1:41.57, the first time any Olympic alpine event had ended in a tie for the gold. [[Lara Gut]] of Switzerland finished 0.10 seconds behind to pick up the bronze medal.<ref name="Day6-Alpine skiing-women's downhill">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-downhill-at-rosa-khutor-one-gold-for-two | title=Downhill at Rosa Khutor: one gold for two | work=Sochi 2014 | date=12 February 2014 | accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] *[[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 4 *** {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} 5–9 '''{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}}''' 8–5 {{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' 5–4 {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} ** Round robin, draw 5 *** {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} 2–4 '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} 7–11 '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' 8–5 {{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} 4–7 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' *[[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 4 *** '''{{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}}''' 8–4 {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 4–7 '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}} 4–7 '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 9–6 {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Pair skating|pair skating]] gold medal went to Russia's [[Tatiana Volosozhar]] and [[Maxim Trankov]]. They scored 152.69 in the free program, and combined with their score in the short program, 236.86 overall. Russia's [[Ksenia Stolbova]] and [[Fedor Klimov]] scored 143.47 in the free program to hold onto the silver with a combined score of 218.68. China's [[Pang Qing]] and [[Tong Jian]] came third in the free program with a score of 136.58, but Germany's [[Aliona Savchenko]] and [[Robin Szolkowy]] instead took the bronze with a total score of 215.78.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/12/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-five-live |title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day five – as it happened |date=12 February 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="Day6-Figure skating-pairs">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-tatiana-volosozhar-maxim-trankov-win-gold-in-pair-skating | title=Tatiana Volosozhar/Maxim Trankov win gold in pair skating | work=Sochi 2014 | date=12 February 2014 | accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group C *** {{ih|CZE}} 2–4 '''{{ih|SWE}}''' *** {{ih|LAT}} 0–1 '''{{ih|SUI}}''' * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group A *** {{ihw|SUI}} 3–4 OT '''{{ihw|FIN}}''' *** '''{{ihw|CAN}}''' 3–2 {{ihw|USA}}
;[[Image:Luge pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Doubles|doubles event]] saw [[Tobias Wendl]] and [[Tobias Arlt]] (Germany) finishing both runs with the fastest times, thus winning the gold with a combined time of 1:38.933. [[Andreas Linger]] and [[Wolfgang Linger]] (Austria) finished both runs in the second fastest time, finishing second overall. Brothers [[Andris Šics|Andris]] and [[Juris Šics]] (Latvia) finished in third.<ref name="Day6-Luge-doubles">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-germany-earn-third-luge-gold-in-doubles | title=Germany earn third luge gold in doubles | work=Sochi 2014 | date=12 February 2014 | accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Nordic combined pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] * [[Eric Frenzel]] (Germany) won the gold medal in the [[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Individual normal hill/10 km|individual normal hill/10 km]]. Frenzel recorded the farthest distance (103.0m) in the ski jumping section of the event, with [[Akito Watabe]] (Japan) and [[Evgeni Klimov (nordic combined skier)|Evgeni Klimov]] (Russia) finishing second and third, respectively. The fastest time in the cross-country section was posted by [[Alessandro Pittin]] (Italy), but with the combined scores, Frenzel and Watabe were able to stay in the gold and silver positions, respectively. [[Magnus Krog]] (Norway) took with the bronze.<ref name="Day6-Nordic-10km">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-eric-frenzel-wins-first-nordic-combined-gold-of-sochi-2014 | title=Eric Frenzel wins first Nordic combined gold of Sochi 2014 | work=Sochi 2014 | date=12 February 2014 | accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|women's halfpipe]], [[Kaitlyn Farrington]] (USA) won the gold with a score of 91.75, while [[Torah Bright]] (Australia) finished second, just 0.25 points behind, and [[Kelly Clark]] (USA) finished third with a score of 90.75.<ref name="Day6-Snowboarding-women's halfpipe">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-ladies-hp-finals | title=Ladies' Halfpipe Final Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=12 February 2014 | accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref> The competition began with the qualifying round, with Clark winning Heat 1 with a score of 95.00, and Bright winning the second heat, scoring 93.00. Along with four others, they advanced to the final. The next six best placed athletes in each heat qualified for the semifinal, with Farrington scoring 87.50 to qualify for the final along with five others.
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * In the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|men's 1000 metres]], the Netherlands continued their dominance of the speed skating events by picking up another two medals. [[Stefan Groothuis]] finished first, with his time of 1:08.39, a track record. [[Michel Mulder]] finished third. The silver medal, though, went to Canadian [[Denny Morrison]], just 0.04 seconds behind the leader.<ref name="Day6-Speed skating-men's 1000m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-stefan-groothuis-keeps-dutch-speed-skating-medal-train-rolling-on | title=Stefan Groothuis keeps Dutch speed skating medal train rolling on | work=Sochi 2014 | date=12 February 2014 | accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="6" | Gold medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |rowspan=2|[[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] |rowspan=2|[[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's downhill|Women's downhill]] |[[Tina Maze]] |{{flagIOC|SLO|2014 Winter}} |rowspan=2| | rowspan="2" |<ref name="Day6-Alpine skiing-women's downhill" /> |- |[[Dominique Gisin]] |{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} |- |[[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] |[[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Pair skating|Pair skating]] |[[Tatiana Volosozhar]]<br>[[Maxim Trankov]] |{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day6-Figure skating-pairs" /> |- |[[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]] |[[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Doubles|Doubles]] |[[Tobias Arlt]]<br/>[[Tobias Wendl]] |{{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day6-Luge-doubles" /> |- |[[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] |[[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Individual normal hill/10 km|Individual normal hill/10 km]] |[[Eric Frenzel]] |{{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day6-Nordic-10km" /> |- |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|Women's halfpipe]] |[[Kaitlyn Farrington]] |{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day6-Snowboarding-women's halfpipe" /> |- |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|Men's 1000 metres]] |[[Stefan Groothuis]] |{{flagIOC|NED|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day6-Speed skating-men's 1000m" /> |}
==Day 7 – Thursday 13 February== ;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's individual|men's individual]] gold medal went to [[Martin Fourcade]] (France), who had a time of 49:31.7. [[Erik Lesser]] (Germany) finished with no penalties, in a time of 49:43.9, for the silver medal, and [[Evgeniy Garanichev]] (Russia) finishing third at 50:06.2.<ref name="Day7-Biathlon-men's individual">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-france-s-martin-fourcade-wins-second-gold-in-sochi | title=France’s Martin Fourcade wins second gold in Sochi | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 10 kilometre classical|women's 10 km classical]], [[Justyna Kowalczyk]] (Poland) finished first with a time of 28:17.8, with [[Charlotte Kalla]] (Sweden) 18.4 seconds behind in second place. [[Therese Johaug]] (Norway) finished third.<ref name="Day7-Cross country-women's 10km">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-justyna-kowalczyk-is-the-best-in-classic-sprint| title=Justyna Kowalczyk is the best in classic sprint | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 6 *** {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} 6–7 '''{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 7–6 {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} 4–5 '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' 5–3 {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 5 *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 8–5 {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} 7–8 '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} 8–9 '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' ** Round robin, draw 6 *** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 7–6 {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} 4–8 '''{{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} 5–8 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}} 6–8 '''{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}}'''
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * [[Yuzuru Hanyu]] (Japan) led the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles short program]] with a score of 101.45, becoming the first skater to break the 100-point mark in the short program. [[Patrick Chan]] (Canada) finished the short program in second, with a score of 97.52, and [[Javier Fernández (figure skater)|Javier Fernández]] (Spain) finished third. Overall, 24 athletes advanced to the free skating section of the event.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-men-short-program | title=Figure Skating – Men's Short Program Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * All three medals of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|men's slopestyle]] were won by Americans. In the qualification round, [[Joss Christensen]] (USA) scored 93.2, with [[Andreas Håtveit]] (Norway) finishing second, and [[James Woods (freestyle skier)|James Woods]] (Great Britain) finished third. The top 12 athletes advanced to the final, where Christensen scored 95.80 to win the gold, American [[Gus Kenworthy]] took the silver, and [[Nick Goepper]] of USA finished third.<ref name="Day7-Freestyle skiing-men's slopestyle">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/13/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-six-live |title=Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day six – as it happened |date=13 February 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group A *** '''{{ih|RUS}}''' 5–2 {{ih|SVN}} *** {{ih|SVK}} 1–7 '''{{ih|USA}}''' ** Preliminary round – Group B *** '''{{ih|FIN}}''' 8–4 {{ih|AUT}} *** '''{{ih|CAN}}''' 3–1 {{ih|NOR}} * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group B *** {{ihw|JPN}} 0–4 '''{{ihw|GER}}''' *** {{ihw|SWE}} 1–3 '''{{ihw|RUS}}'''
;[[Image:Luge pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The [[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Team relay|team relay]] gold medal went to the German team, consisting of [[Natalie Geisenberger]], [[Felix Loch]] and [[Tobias Wendl]] / [[Tobias Arlt]], with a total time of 2:45.649. The Russian team ([[Tatiana Ivanova]], [[Albert Demchenko]] and [[Alexander Denisyev]] / [[Vladislav Antonov]]) finished second, with Latvia ([[Elīza Tīruma]], [[Mārtiņš Rubenis]] and [[Andris Šics|Andris]] / [[Juris Šics]]) picking up the bronze medal.<ref name="Day7-Luge-Team">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-german-team-won-gold-in-luge-relay| title=German team won gold in luge relay, Russia is the second, bronze went to Latvia | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * The [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|women's 500 metres]] gold medal went to [[Li Jianrou]] of China. At the start of the day, the fastest times in the quarterfinals came from [[Fan Kexin]] (China), [[Park Seung-Hi]] (South Korea) and [[Elise Christie]] (Great Britain), with eight athletes advancing to the semifinals overall. The first semifinal was then won by [[Park Seung-Hi]] (South Korea), with [[Elise Christie]] (Great Britain) winning the second semifinal. The top two in each semifinal advanced to Final A (the medal round), with the other four athletes moving on to Final B (to determine 5th place and below). In Final A, [[Li Jianrou]] (China) finished first, in a time of 45.263. [[Elise Christie]] (Great Britain) finished the race second, but was later given a penalty, moving her down to 8th position overall. Thus, [[Arianna Fontana]] (Italy) finished with the silver medal, and [[Park Seung-Hi]] finished with the bronze.<ref name="Day7-Short track-women's 500m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-the-olympic-gold-in-500m-ladies-short-track-goes-to-china | title=The Olympic gold in 500m ladies’ short track goes to China | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref> In Final B, [[Liu Quihong]] (China) finished first in a time of 44.188, moving her up to 4th place overall as a result of Christie's penalty. * The [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metre relay|men's 5000 metre relay]] semifinals were held. The first semifinal was won by the Netherlands team, consisting of [[Daan Breeuwsma]], [[Niels Kerstholt]], [[Sjinkie Knegt]] and [[Freek van der Wart]], in a time of 6:45.385. The second semifinal was won in a faster time of 6:44.331, by Russia ([[Viktor Ahn]], [[Semen Elistratov]], [[Vladimir Grigorev]] and [[Ruslan Zakharov]]).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/short-track-men-s-5000-m-relay-semifinals | title=Short Track – Men's 5000 m Relay Semifinals Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref> China, Kazakhstan and USA, as well as these two teams, will compete in Final A, with Italy, Canada and South Korea competing in Final B. * In the heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|men's 1000 metres]], the fastest times being posted by [[Charle Cournoyer]] (Canada) and [[Wu Dajing]] (China).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/short-track-men-s-1000-m-heats | title=Short Track – Men's 1000 m Heats Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref> The top two from each of the eight heats advanced to the quarterfinals.
;[[Image:Skeleton pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Skeleton at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Skeleton]] * The first two runs of the [[Skeleton at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's|women's skeleton event]] were held. [[Lizzy Yarnold]] (Great Britain) established a track record (58.43) in the first run, finishing the day with the fastest time. [[Noelle Pikus-Pace]] (USA) finished the day in second, whilst [[Elena Nikitina]] (Russia) set a new start record (4.89), finishing the day in third.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/skeleton-women-s-heat-2-02 | title=Skeleton – Women's Heat 2 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * In the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|women's 1000 metres]], [[Zhang Hong (speed skater)|Zhang Hong]] (China) set a new track record, taking the gold medal with a time of 1:14.02. [[Ireen Wüst]] and [[Margot Boer]] (both Netherlands) finished second and third.<ref name="Day7-Speed skating-women's 1000m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-zhang-hong-from-china-won-1000-m-speed-skating | title=Zhang Hong from China won 1000 m speed skating | work=Sochi 2014 | date=13 February 2014 | accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="6" | Gold medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's individual|Men's individual]] |[[Martin Fourcade]] |{{flagIOC|FRA|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day7-Biathlon-men's individual" /> |- |[[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] |[[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 10 kilometre classical|Women's 10 km classical]] |[[Justyna Kowalczyk]] |{{flagIOC|POL|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day7-Cross country-women's 10km" /> |- |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|Men's slopestyle]] |[[Joss Christensen]] |{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day7-Freestyle skiing-men's slopestyle" /> |- |[[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Luge]] |[[Luge at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Team relay|Team relay]] |[[Natalie Geisenberger]]<br>[[Felix Loch]]<br>[[Tobias Wendl]] / [[Tobias Arlt]] |{{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day7-Luge-Team" /> |- |[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] |[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|Women's 500 metres]] |[[Li Jianrou]] |{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day7-Short track-women's 500m" /> |- |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|Women's 1000 metres]] |[[Zhang Hong (speed skater)|Zhang Hong]] |{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day7-Speed skating-women's 1000m" /> |}
==Day 8 – Friday 14 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * [[Sandro Viletta]] (Switzerland) won the gold in the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's combined|men's combined]] with the fastest overall time, 2:45.20, with [[Ivica Kostelić]] (Croatia) finishing second and [[Christof Innerhofer]] (Italy) taking the bronze. [[Kjetil Jansrud]] (Norway) finished with the fastest downhill time (1:53.24), with [[Adam Žampa]] (Slovakia) recording the fastest slalom time (50.11).<ref name="Day8-Alpine skiing-Men's combined">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/alpine-skiing-men-s-super-combined-slalom | title=Alpine Skiing – Men's Super Combined Slalom results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=14 February 2014 | accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * In the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's individual|women's individual]], [[Darya Domracheva]] (Belarus) finished the race in 43:19.6 (with 1 penalty), to pick up the gold medal. [[Selina Gasparin]] (Switzerland) finished second with no penalties, as did [[Nadezhda Skardino]] (Belarus) in third place.<ref name="Day8-Biathlon-Women's individual">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/biathlon-women-s-15-km-individual | title=Biathlon – Women's 15km Individual Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=14 February 2014 | accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 15 kilometre classical|men's 15 km classical]], [[Dario Cologna]] (Switzerland) finished in 38:29.7 to secure the gold medal, with [[Johan Olsson (skier)|Johan Olsson]] and [[Daniel Richardsson]] (both Sweden) finishing second and third.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/cross-country-men-s-15-km-classic | title=Cross Country – Men's 15km Classic Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=14 February 2014 | accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 7 *** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 6–5 {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}}''' 8–5 {{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 10–4 {{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} ** Round robin, draw 8 *** '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' 8–6 {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}}''' 7–6 {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' 7–5 {{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} 7–8 '''{{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}}''' * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 7 *** {{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}} 3–11 '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' 12–3 {{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}} **** Great Britain equalled an Olympic record with this result, a feat they had also achieved in [[#Day 5 – Tuesday 11 February|draw 3]]. *** {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 2–9 '''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}}''' 6–3 {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * In the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]], [[Yuzuru Hanyu]] (Japan) won the gold, finished first in the free skating with a score of 178.64, and a score of 280.09 overall. [[Patrick Chan]] (Canada) and [[Denis Ten]] (Kazakhstan) posted the next best scores in the free skating, earning them silver and bronze, respectively.<ref name="Day8-Figure Skating-Men's Singles">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-men-free-skating | title=Figure Skating – Men's Free Program Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=14 February 2014 | accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * In the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's aerials|women's aerials]], [[Alla Tsuper]] (Belarus) won the gold medal. The day began with the first qualifying round, with [[Ashley Caldwell]] (USA) finishing with a score of 101.5, and [[Li Nina]] (China) and [[Danielle Scott (freestyle skier)|Danielle Scott]] (Australia) in second and third. Three other athletes advanced to the finals. The other athletes competed in the second qualifying round, with [[Lydia Lassila]] (Australia) finishing first with a score of 90.65. Her and five others moved on to the finals. In the first final, [[Alla Tsuper]] (Belarus) finished with the highest score (99.18), with the top eight athletes moving on. In the second final, [[Xu Mengtao]] (China) posted a score of 101.08, moving on to the final round along with three others. Tsuper then picked up the gold medal with a score of 98.01 in the final round, with Xu Mengtao taking the silver and Lassila the bronze.<ref name="Day8-Freestyle Skiing-Women's Aerials">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-ladies-aerials-final-3 | title=Freestyle Skiing – Women's Aerials Final 3 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=14 February 2014 | accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group B *** '''{{ih|CAN}}''' 6–0 {{ih|AUT}} *** {{ih|NOR}} 1–6 '''{{ih|FIN}}''' ** Preliminary round – Group C *** '''{{ih|CZE}}''' 4–2 {{ih|LAT}} *** '''{{ih|SWE}}''' 1–0 {{ih|SUI}}
;[[Image:Skeleton pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Skeleton at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Skeleton]] * In the [[Skeleton at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's|women's event]], [[Lizzy Yarnold]] finished with the gold medal, retaining the medal for Great Britain, in a total time of 3:52.89. 0.97 seconds behind was [[Noelle Pikus-Pace]] (USA), with [[Elena Nikitina]] (Russia) in third. Yarnold continued her form from the first two runs, to finish the third run with the fastest time, beating her own track record from run one. [[Olga Potylitsina]] (Russia) completed the third run in the second fastest time, with [[Noelle Pikus-Pace]] (USA) third. In the fourth and final run, [[Lizzy Yarnold]] (Great Britain) again finished with the fastest time, with [[Sarah Reid (curler)|Sarah Reid]] and [[Mellisa Hollingsworth]] (both Canada) both recording identical times for second place in this run.<ref name="Day8-Skeleton-Women's">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/skeleton-women-s-heat-4-04 | title=Skeleton – Women's Heat 4 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=14 February 2014 | accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * In the [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill individual|men's large hill individual]] qualification round, [[Michael Hayböck]] (Austria) finished with a total score of 124.8. [[Daiki Ito]] and [[Reruhi Shimizu]] (both Japan) finished second and third.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/ski-jumping-men-s-large-hill-ind-qual-round | title=Ski Jumping – Men's Large Hill Individual Qualification Round Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=14 February 2014 | accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref> The top 40 athletes advanced to the next round.

==Day 9 – Saturday 15 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] *In the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's super-G|women's super-G]], [[Anna Fenninger]] (Austria) won the gold with a time of 1:25.52, while [[Maria Höfl-Riesch]] (Germany) was 0.55 behind to win the silver and [[Nicole Hosp]] (Austria) was 0.66 behind to win the bronze.<ref name="Day9-Alpine skiing-women's super-G">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-fenninger-wins-women-s-super-g | title=Fenninger wins women's super-G | work=Sochi 2014 | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 4 × 5 kilometre relay|women's 4 x 5 km relay]] gold medal was awarded to Sweden. Led by [[Charlotte Kalla]]'s last leg of 12:10.4, she, [[Ida Ingemarsdotter]], [[Emma Wikén]] and [[Anna Haag]] recorded a total time of 53:02.7. Finland ([[Anne Kyllönen]], [[Aino-Kaisa Saarinen]], [[Kerttu Niskanen]] and [[Krista Lähteenmäki]]) finished in second at 0.5 seconds behind, and Germany ([[Nicole Fessel]], [[Stefanie Böhler]], [[Claudia Nystad]] and [[Denise Herrmann]]) in third at 0.9 behind, but 44.1 seconds ahead of fourth placed France.<ref name="Day9-Cross country-women's 4x5 km">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-sweden-wins-gold-in-skiing-after-persistent-fight | title=Sweden wins gold in skiing after persistent fight | work=Sochi 2014 | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 9 *** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 8–4 {{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 7–5 {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}} 3–9 '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} 6–9 '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 8 *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 8–6 {{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' 7–6 {{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' 10–8 {{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}} ** Round robin, draw 9 *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 5–3 {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 6–7 '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} 6–8 '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' 9–6 {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group A *** {{ih|SVK}} 1–3 '''{{ih|SLO}}''' *** '''{{ih|USA}}''' 3–2 ([[Shootout (ice hockey)|GWS]]) {{ih|RUS}} ** Preliminary round – Group C *** '''{{ih|SWE}}''' 5–3 {{ih|LAT}} *** '''{{ih|SUI}}''' 1–0 {{ih|CZE}} *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] **Play-offs – Quarterfinals *** {{ihw|FIN}} 2–4 '''{{ihw|SWE}}''' *** '''{{ihw|SUI}}''' 2–0 {{ihw|RUS}}
;[[Image:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * The [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1500 metres|women's 1500 metres]] gold medal went to [[Zhou Yang (speed skater)|Zhou Yang]] (China), while [[Shim Suk-Hee]] (South Korea) took silver and [[Arianna Fontana]] (Italy) the bronze. At the start of the day, the top three from each of the six heats qualified for the semifinals. The three winning athletes in heat four produced the fastest times, with [[Jorien ter Mors]] (Netherlands) recording the fastest with a time of 2:21.626. [[Elise Christie]] (Great Britain) was penalised for the [[#Day 7 – Thursday 13 February|second time]] of the Games, with a DNF, for missing the finish line by about 1 cm, despite appearing to win her heat. In the semifinals, the top two in each of the three races qualified for Final A (medal round), while the next two qualified for Final B (qualification round); Zhou Yang recorded the fastest time (2:18.825). In Final A, Zhou Yang finished first in 2:19.140 with Shim Suk-Hee finishing second at 2:19.239 and Arianna Fontana third at 2:19.416. [[Valérie Maltais]] recorded the fastest time in Final B (2:24.711) to place in 6th overall. * In the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|men's 1000 metres]], [[Viktor Ahn]] of Russia finished Final A (medal round) with a time of 1:25.325 to win the gold medal. Russian [[Vladimir Grigorev]] earned the silver at 1:25.399 and Dutch [[Sjinkie Knegt]] got the bronze at 1:25.611.<ref name="Day9-Short track speed skating">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-short-track-russian-athletes-triumph | title=Short Track: Russian athletes triumph | work=Sochi 2014 | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref> The day began with the quarterfinals, where the top two from each of the four races advanced to the semifinals; the fastest time was recorded by [[Charles Hamelin]] (Canada) in heat three, 1:40.408. The top two in each semifinal then advanced to Final A, with the others competing in classification round Final B. Viktor Ahn recorded the best time (1:24.102) in the second semifinal. [[Han Tianyu]] (China) won Final B with a time of 1:29.334 to finish 5th overall.
;[[Image:Skeleton pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Skeleton at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Skeleton]] * The final two runs (runs 3 and 4) of the [[Skeleton at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's|men's event]] took place. [[Aleksandr Tretyakov (skeleton racer)|Aleksandr Tretyakov]] (Russia) finished with the gold medal with a total time of 3:44.29. Just coming 0.81 seconds behind, [[Martins Dukurs]] became the first athlete from Latvia to win two silver medals (previously winning the silver in [[Skeleton at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's|the same event during the 2010 Olympics]]). [[Matthew Antoine]] of the United States took the bronze.<ref name="Day9-Short track speed skating">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-short-track-russian-athletes-triumph | title=Short Track: Russian athletes triumph | work=Sochi 2014 | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref> Dukurs recorded the fastest time in the third run at 56.26 while Tretyakov led with 56.02 seconds in the fourth run.
;[[Image:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * In the [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill individual|men's large hill individual]], Poland's [[Kamil Stoch]] earned his second gold medal in the 2014 Olympics, recording an overall score of 278.7 in the two rounds of the final. Japan's [[Noriaki Kasai]] was second at 277.4 overall and Slovenia's [[Peter Prevc]] was third overall at 274.8.<ref name="Day9-Ski jumping-men's large hill">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-kamil-stoch-wins-second-gold-of-sochi-2014 | title=Kamil Stoch wins second gold of Sochi 2014 | work=Sochi 2014 | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref> Stoch led the first round with 143.4 points. Prevc led the final round with 140.3 points, but dropped to the bronze medal because he finished fourth in the first round.
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] *In the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|men's 1500 metres]], [[Zbigniew Bródka]] of Poland finished just 0.003 seconds in front of [[Koen Verweij]] of the Netherlands to win the gold medal, while Canada's [[Denny Morrison]] took the bronze at 0.022 seconds behind.<ref name="Day9-Speed skating-men's 1500m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-poland-s-zbigniew-brodka-won-the-men-s-1500m-long-track-speed-skating-gold | title=Poland’s Zbigniew Brodka won the men's 1500m long track speed skating gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref> The track record was broken three times during the day, first by [[Mark Tuitert]] (Netherlands) in the 13th pair with a time of 1:45.42, then by [[Denny Morrison]] (Canada) by 0.2 seconds in the 13th pair, and finally by Bródka in the 17th pair, en route to his gold medal win, with a time of 1:45.006.
