==Day 10 – Sunday 16 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's super-G|men's super-G]] gold medal was awarded to [[Kjetil Jansrud]] of Norway with a time of 1:18.14. [[Andrew Weibrecht]] of the United States finished 0.30 seconds back to earn the silver. Canadian [[Jan Hudec]] and American [[Bode Miller]] tied for the bronze medal at 0.53 seconds back.<ref name="Day10-Alpine skiing-Men's super-G">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-norwegian-kjetil-jansrud-won-the-olympic-gold-in-super-g | title=Norwegian Kjetil Jansrud won the Olympic gold in Super-G | work=Sochi 2014 | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/16/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-nine-live|title= Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics – day nine as it happened|date=16 February 2014|work=Guardian|accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's mass start|men's mass start]] race was postponed to the [[#Day 11 – Monday 17 February|following morning]] due to thick fog.<ref>{{cite web|title = Men’s Mass Start Moved to Monday at 10 AM Local Time|url = http://www3.biathlonworld.com/en/press_releases.html/do/detail?presse=2133|publisher = [[International Biathlon Union]]|accessdate = 16 February 2014|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140217091910/http://www4.biathlonworld.com/en/press_releases.html/do/detail?presse=2133#|archive-date = 17 February 2014|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
;[[Image:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * In the [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Two-man|two-man event]], the Russian team of [[Alexandr Zubkov]] and [[Alexey Voyevoda]] recorded the fastest times in the first two runs.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/bobsleigh-two-man-heat-2 | title=Bobsleigh-Two-man Heat 2 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref> Their time of 56.25 in the first run was a track record.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/bobsleigh-two-man-heat-1 | title=Bobsleigh-Two-man Heat 1 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 4 × 10 kilometre relay|men's 4 × 10 km relay]], the Swedish team of [[Lars Nelson (skier)|Lars Nelson]], [[Daniel Richardsson]], [[Johan Olsson (skier)|Johan Olsson]] and [[Marcus Hellner]] led throughout most of the race to win the gold. The silver went to Russia and the bronze went to France.<ref name="Day10-Cross country-Men's 4x10km">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-the-swedish-skiing-team-takes-gold-in-the-relay | title=The Swedish skiing team takes gold in the relay | work=Sochi 2014 | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 10 *** {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 6–8 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} 6–7 '''{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 8–4 {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} ** Round robin, draw 11 *** '''{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}}''' 5–3 {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} 8–9 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} 3–6 '''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' *** {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 4–6 '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 10 *** '''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' 7–4 {{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}}''' 9–7 {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 5–4 {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} 6–7 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}'''
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] *In the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing|ice dancing competition]], Americans [[Meryl Davis]] and [[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]] set a world record score of 78.89 in the short program.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-ice-dancers-meryl-davis-and-charlie-white-usa-take-short-step-to-lead | title=Ice dancers Meryl Davis and Charlie White (USA) take short step to lead | work=Sochi 2014 | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref> The top 20 pairs advanced to the free program.
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Preliminary round – Group A *** '''{{ih|RUS}}''' 1–0 ([[Shootout (ice hockey)|GWS]]) {{ih|SVK}} *** {{ih|SLO}} 1–5 '''{{ih|USA}}''' ** Preliminary round – Group B *** '''{{ih|AUT}}''' 3–1 {{ih|NOR}} *** {{ih|FIN}} 1–2 '''{{ih|CAN}}''' *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] **5–8th place play-offs – Semifinals *** '''{{ihw|FIN}}''' 2–1 {{ihw|GER}} *** '''{{ihw|RUS}}''' 6–3 {{ihw|JPN}}
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The Czech Republic's [[Eva Samková]] won the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's snowboard cross|women's snowboard cross]] gold medal. She began the day recording the fastest time in the Seeding round. Then, after two rounds of six-person elimination races, with the top three from each race advancing, Samková finished first in the final, while [[Dominique Maltais]] of Canada won the silver, and France's [[Chloé Trespeuch]] won the bronze.<ref name="Day10-Snowboarding-Women's cross">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-eva-samkov-brings-the-czech-team-s-its-first-gold-medal | title=Eva Samková brings the Czech team's its first gold medal | work=Sochi 2014 | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1500 metres|women's 1500 metres]] medals all went to the Netherlands. [[Jorien ter Mors]] set an Olympic record of 1:53.51 to win the gold, while [[Ireen Wüst]] took the silver at 0.58 seconds back, and [[Lotte van Beek]] finished third at 1.03 seconds back.<ref name="Day10-Speed skating-Women's 1500m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-dutch-1-2-3-in-women-s-1-500m-speed-skating | title=Dutch 1–2–3 in women's 1,500m speed skating | work=Sochi 2014 | date=16 February 2014 | accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref> With this medal sweep, Netherlands became the first country in history to earn three podium sweeps at the same Olympic Winter Games. This was actually a quadruple sweep, because fourth place went to the Netherlands as well, [[Marrit Leenstra (speed skater)|Marrit Leenstra]] finished fourth with time 1:56.40.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="6" | Gold medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |[[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] |[[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's super-G|Men's super-G]] |[[Kjetil Jansrud]] |{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day10-Alpine skiing-Men's super-G" /> |- |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's mass start|Men's mass start]] |colspan=3 align="center"| ''Postponed'' |<ref>{{cite news |work=ESPN |agency=Associated Press |title=Men's biathlon race postponed |url=http://espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2014/biathlon/story/_/id/10465274/2014-sochi-olympics-men-biathlon-race-postponed-due-fog |accessdate=16 February 2014 |date=16 February 2014}}</ref> |- |[[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] |[[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 4 × 10 kilometre relay|Men's 4 × 10 km relay]] |[[Lars Nelson (skier)|Lars Nelson]] <br/> [[Daniel Richardsson]] <br/> [[Johan Olsson (skier)|Johan Olsson]] <br/> [[Marcus Hellner]] |{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day10-Cross country-Men's 4x10km" /> |- |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's snowboard cross|Women's snowboard cross]] |[[Eva Samková]] |{{flagIOC|CZE|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day10-Snowboarding-Women's cross" /> |- |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] |[[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1500 metres|Women's 1500 metres]] |[[Jorien ter Mors]] |{{flagIOC|NED|2014 Winter}} |[[List of speed skating records#Women 3|OR]] |<ref name="Day10-Speed skating-Women's 1500m" /> |}
==Day 11 – Monday 17 February== ;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's mass start|men's mass start]] was postponed again to [[#Day 11 – Tuesday 18 February|Tuesday afternoon]] due to more dense fog.<ref name="Day11-Biathlon-Postponement">{{cite news |work=NBC Olympics |agency=NBC |title=Men’s biathlon 15km mass start delayed by fog (again) |url=http://olympictalk.nbcsports.com/2014/02/17/mens-biathlon-15km-mass-start-delayed-by-fog-again/ |accessdate=17 February 2014 |date=17 February 2014}}</ref> * In the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's mass start|women's mass start]], [[Darya Domracheva]] (Belarus) finished with one penalty in 35:25.6 to secure the gold medal. [[Gabriela Soukalová]] (Czech Republic) finished second, with [[Tiril Eckhoff]] (Norway) third.<ref name="Day11-Biathlon-Women's mass start">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/biathlon-women-s-12-5-km-mass-start | title=Biathlon – Women's 12.5 km Mass Start Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=17 February 2014 | accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/17/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-10-live|title= Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day 10 – as it happened!|date=17 February 2014|work=Guardian|accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * In the [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Two-man|two-man]], the Russian pair of [[Alexandr Zubkov]] and [[Alexey Voyevoda]] finished with 3:45.39 overall to win the gold. They recorded the fastest times in both of the two final runs, and beat the track record in Run 3 that they had previous set in Run 1 of the event. Switzerland's team of [[Beat Hefti]] and [[Alex Baumann (bobsleigh)|Alex Baumann]] took the silver, and Americans [[Steven Holcomb]] and [[Steven Langton]] got the bronze.<ref name="Day11-Bobsleigh-Two man">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-russia-win-two-man-bobsleigh | title=Russia win two-man bobsleigh | work=Sochi 2014 | date=17 February 2014 | accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 12 *** '''{{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}}''' 6–5 {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} 7–8 '''{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' 6–3 {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} 3–5 '''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Round robin, draw 11 *** {{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} 6–9 '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}}''' 11–2 {{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}}''' 8–5 {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} ** Round robin, draw 12 *** {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} 6–10 '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}''' *** '''{{flagIOC|DEN|2014 Winter}}''' 8–7 {{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 9–4 {{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}} *** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 8–4 {{flagIOC|JPN|2014 Winter}}
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing|ice dancing]] gold medal went to [[Meryl Davis]] and [[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]], the first Americans to win the gold in this event. Canadians [[Tessa Virtue]] and [[Scott Moir]] set a world record in the free program with a score of 114.66 moments before Davis and White broke it with a score of 116.63. The Americans thus secured first overall with a world record score of 195.52. Virtue and Moir received the silver and Russians [[Elena Ilinykh]] and [[Nikita Katsalapov]] finished with the bronze.<ref name="Day11-Figure Skating-Ice Dancing">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-meryl-davis-and-charlie-white-claim-first-ice-dancing-gold-for-usa | title=Meryl Davis and Charlie White claim first ice dancing gold for USA | work=Sochi 2014 | date=17 February 2014 | accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle]] * The [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's aerials|men's aerials]] gold medal was awarded to [[Anton Kushnir]] (Belarus). The day began with the two qualification rounds. In the first qualification round, [[Jia Zongyang]] (China) and [[David Morris (skier)|David Morris]] (Australia) finished with a score of 118.59 each, to progress with four other athletes to the finals. In the second qualification round, [[Dmitri Dashinski]] (Belarus) scored 117.19 to progress with five other athletes to the finals. The finals then consisted of three rounds. In the first round of the finals, [[Qi Guangpu]] (China) recorded the best score of 121.24, with the best eight remaining in the competition. [[Jia Zongyang]] (China) scored 117.70, the highest in the second round, with the top four progressing to the final round. Anton Kushnir then scored 134.50 in the final round to win gold, while David Morris took the silver with 110.41 and Jia Zongyang the bronze at 95.06.<ref name="Day11-Freestyle skiing-Men's aerials">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-men-s-aerials-final-3 | title=Freestyle skiing – Men's Aerials Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=17 February 2014 | accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Final round – Semifinals *** '''{{ihw|USA}}''' 6–1 {{ihw|SWE}} *** '''{{ihw|CAN}}''' 3–1 {{ihw|SUI}}
;[[Image:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * In the [[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill team|men's large hill team]], Germany won the gold, Austria won the silver, and Japan won the bronze. The first round was led by the [[Germany at the 2014 Winter Olympics|German]] team ([[Andreas Wank]], [[Marinus Kraus]], [[Andreas Wellinger]] and [[Severin Freund]]), scoring 519.0 points. The top eight teams then advanced to the final round, where the [[Poland at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Polish]] team ([[Maciej Kot]], [[Piotr Żyła]], [[Jan Ziobro]] and [[Kamil Stoch]]) scored the highest with 522.6 points. But overall, the German team finished with a total of 1041.1 points to secure the gold medal, while [[Austria at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Austria]] ([[Michael Hayböck]], [[Thomas Morgenstern]], [[Thomas Diethart]] and [[Gregor Schlierenzauer]]) finished second at 1038.4 overall, and [[Japan at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Japan]] ([[Reruhi Shimizu]], [[Taku Takeuchi]], [[Daiki Ito]] and [[Noriaki Kasai]]) finished third with 1024.9.<ref name="Day11-Ski jumping-Men's large hill team">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/ski-jumping-men-s-team-final-round | title=Ski Jumping – Men's Team Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=17 February 2014 | accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * Because of dense fog, the seeding run of the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's snowboard cross|men's snowboard cross]] was cancelled. Instead, the seedings for the finals will be based on the latest World Cup standings. The finals were then rescheduled to [[#Day 11 – Tuesday 18 February|Tuesday morning]].<ref name="Day11-Snowboarding-Postponement">{{cite web | url=http://espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2014/snowboarding/story/_/id/10469211/2014-sochi-olympics-men-snowboardcross-postponed-fog | title=Fog postpones snowboardcross race | agency=ESPN | date=17 February 2014 | accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="6" | Gold medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |rowspan="2"|[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's mass start|Men's mass start]] |colspan=3 align="center"| ''Postponed'' |<ref name="Day11-Biathlon-Postponement"/> |- |[[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's mass start|Women's mass start]] |[[Darya Domracheva]] |{{flagIOC|BLR|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day11-Biathlon-Women's mass start"/> |- |[[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] |[[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Two-man|Two-man]] |[[Alexander Zubkov]]<br/>[[Alexey Voevoda]] |{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day11-Bobsleigh-Two man"/> |- |[[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] |[[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing|Ice dancing]] |[[Meryl Davis]]<br/>[[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]] |{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} |[[ISU Judging System#Ice dancing|WR]] |<ref name="Day11-Figure Skating-Ice Dancing"/> |- |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's aerials|Men's aerials]] |[[Anton Kushnir]] |{{flagIOC|BLR|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day11-Freestyle skiing-Men's aerials"/> |- |[[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] |[[Ski jumping at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill team|Men's large hill team]] |[[Andreas Wank]]<br/>[[Marinus Kraus]]<br/>[[Andreas Wellinger]]<br/>[[Severin Freund]] |{{flagIOC|GER|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day11-Ski jumping-Men's large hill team"/> |- |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] |[[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's snowboard cross|Men's snowboard cross]]
|colspan=3 align="center"| ''Postponed'' |<ref name="Day11-Snowboarding-Postponement"/> |}
==Day 12 – Tuesday 18 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] *In the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's giant slalom|women's giant slalom]], [[Tina Maze]] (Slovenia) won the gold medal, with [[Anna Fenninger]] (Austria) in second, and [[Viktoria Rebensburg]] (Germany) finishing third. Maze recorded the fastest time in the first run with a time of 1:17.88. Rebensburg finished the second run with the fastest time at 1:17.90, but her overall score was 0.27 behind Maze. Fenninger also finished the second run with a faster time than Maze, but ended up with the silver with an overall score that was 0.07 behind.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/18/sochi-2014-winter-olympics-day-11-live|title= Sochi 2014: Winter Olympics day 11 – as it happened|date=18 February 2014|work=Guardian|accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="Day12-Alpine Skiing">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-skier-tina-maze-won-another-gold-in-sochi | title=Skier Tina Maze won another gold in Sochi | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] *After two postponements, the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's mass start|men's mass start]] was finally held. [[Emil Hegle Svendsen]] (Norway) finished first with a time of 42:29.1 and no penalties. [[Martin Fourcade]] (France) finished second, with [[Ondřej Moravec]] (Czech Republic) third.<ref name="Day12-Biathlon">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-norwegian-emil-hegle-svendsen-takes-gold-in-the-men-s-mass-start-biathlon | title=Norwegian Emil Hegle Svendsen takes gold in the men's mass start biathlon | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] *In the [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Two-woman|two-woman]] competition, the American team of [[Elana Meyers]] and [[Lauryn Williams]] finished the first and second runs with the fastest times of 57.26 and 57.63, respectively. The Canadian team of [[Kaillie Humphries]] and [[Heather Moyse]] finished the day in second place, with the second American team of [[Jamie Greubel]] and [[Aja Evans]] in third.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/bobsleigh-women-s-heat-2 | title=Bobsleigh – Women's Heat 2 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Tiebreaker, to qualify for the semifinals ***{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} 5–6 '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}'''
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle]] *In the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's halfpipe|men's halfpipe]], [[David Wise (freestyle skier)|David Wise]] (USA) won the gold medal with a score of 92.00 in the final round. [[Mike Riddle]] (Canada) finished second at 90.60, with [[Kevin Rolland]] (France) in third at 88.60. The day began with the qualification round, where the top twelve athletes advanced to the final; [[Justin Dorey]] (Canada) finished the qualification in first place with a score of 91.60 in the first run.<ref name="Day12-Freestyle Skiing">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-men-s-ski-halfpipe-final | title=Freestyle Skiing – Men's Ski Halfpipe Final Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Qualification playoffs *** '''{{ih|SVN}}''' 4–0 {{ih|AUT}} *** '''{{ih|RUS}}''' 4–0 {{ih|NOR}} *** {{ih|SUI}} 1–3 '''{{ih|LAT}}''' *** '''{{ih|CZE}}''' 5–3 {{ih|SVK}} *[[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Fifth place game *** '''{{ihw|FIN}}''' 4–0 {{ihw|RUS}} ** Seventh place game *** '''{{ihw|GER}}''' 3–2 {{ihw|JPN}}
;[[Image:Nordic combined pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] * In the [[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Individual large hill/10 km|individual large hill/10 km]], [[Jørgen Graabak]] and [[Magnus Moan]] (both Norway) finished with the gold and silver medals. [[Fabian Rießle]] (Germany) finished with the bronze. The ski jumping section was led by [[Eric Frenzel]] (Germany) with 129.0 points, and [[Alessandro Pittin]] (Italy) completed the cross-country section with the fastest time at 22:20.5, but neither Frenzel nor Pittin ranked in the top five overall.<ref name="Day12-Nordic Combined">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-norway-take-gold-in-nordic-combined | title=Norway take gold in nordic combined | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] *In the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|women's 1000m]] qualifying heats, the fastest two athletes in each heat qualified for the quarterfinals. The fastest time was recorded by [[Valérie Maltais]] (Canada) in 1:28.771 in the second heat. *In the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500m]] qualifying heats, the fastest two athletes in each heat qualified for the quarterfinals. The fastest time was recorded by [[Charle Cournoyer]] (Canada) in 41.180 in the second heat. *In the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metre relay|women's 3000 metre relay]] medal round, [[South Korea at the 2014 Winter Olympics|South Korea]] ([[Shim Suk-Hee]], [[Park Seung-Hi]], [[Kim A-Lang]] and [[Cho Ha-Ri]]) finished in the fastest time, 4:09.498 to win gold. [[Canada at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Canada]] ([[Marie-Ève Drolet]], [[Jessica Hewitt]], [[Valérie Maltais]] and [[Marianne St-Gelais]]) finished second, and [[Italy at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Italy]] ([[Arianna Fontana]], [[Lucia Peretti]], [[Martina Valcepina]] and [[Elena Viviani]]) took the bronze medal. This was preceded by the classification final, where the [[Russia at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Russian]] team ([[Olga Belyakova]], [[Tatiana Borodulina]], [[Sofia Prosvirnova]] and [[Valeriya Reznik]]) finished in the fastest time (4:14.862).<ref name="Day12-Short track-Women's 3000m relay">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-south-korea-gain-short-track-relay-gold | title=South Korea gains short track relay gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] *In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's snowboard cross|men's snowboard cross]], [[Pierre Vaultier]] (France) finished first in the large (medal) final to take the gold, [[Nikolay Olyunin]] (Russia) finished with the silver, and [[Alex Deibold]] (USA) captured the bronze. Because of the previous day's cancellation of the seeding rounds, all competitors were seeded in the 1/8 finals based on the World Cup standings, with the top three in each heat qualified for the quarterfinals. [[Alex Pullin]] (Australia), [[Lucas Eguibar]] (Spain), [[Trevor Jacob]] (USA), [[Nikolay Olyunin]] (Russia), [[Konstantin Schad]] (Germany), [[Pierre Vaultier]] (France), [[Paul Berg (snowboarder)|Paul Berg]] (Germany) and [[Cameron Bolton]] (Australia) were the eight heat winners. In the quarterfinals, the top three qualified for the semifinals. [[Lucas Eguibar]] (Spain), [[Nikolay Olyunin]] (Russia), [[Pierre Vaultier]] (France) and [[Cameron Bolton]] (Australia) won their respective quarterfinals. In the semifinals, [[Nikolay Olyunin]] (Russia) and [[Pierre Vaultier]] (France) were the two winners, with the top three from each qualifying to the large (medal) final. [[Lucas Eguibar]] (Spain) won the small final to determine 7th to 12th place.<ref name="Day12-Snowboarding">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-unexpected-conclusion-of-snowboard-race | title=Unexpected conclusion of snowboard cross race | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] *In the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 10000 metres|men's 10000 metres]], the top three skaters were from the Netherlands, the fourth time they had won all three medals in a speed skating event during these Olympics. [[Jorrit Bergsma]] posted a Track and Olympic record time of 12:44.45 to win the gold. [[Sven Kramer]] finished second, with [[Bob de Jong]] finished third.<ref name="Day12-Speed Skating">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-dutch-seal-fourth-podium-sweep-in-10-000m-speed-skate | title=Dutch seal fourth podium sweep in 10,000m speed skate | work=Sochi 2014 | date=18 February 2014 | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref>

==Day 13 – Wednesday 19 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * In the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's giant slalom|men's giant slalom]], [[Ted Ligety]] (USA) took the gold, [[Steve Missillier]] (France) won the silver, and [[Alexis Pinturault]] (France) finished with the bronze. Ligety recorded the fastest time in the first run at 1:21.08. The fastest time of the second run came from Missillier at 1:23.19, but ended up being 0.48 seconds behind overall due to his 10th-place performance in the first run.<ref name="Day13-Alpine Skiing">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/alpine-skiing-men-s-giant-slalom-2nd-run | title=Alpine Skiing - Men's Giant Slalom Run 2 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * In the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Mixed relay|mixed relay]], the [[Norway at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Norwegian]] team of [[Tora Berger]], [[Tiril Eckhoff]], [[Ole Einar Bjørndalen]] and [[Emil Hegle Svendsen]] finished in a combined time of 1:09:17.0, to win gold. The [[Czech Republic at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Czech Republic]] team ([[Veronika Vítková]], [[Gabriela Soukalová]], [[Jaroslav Soukup]] and [[Ondřej Moravec]]) finished second at 32.6 seconds behind, and [[Italy at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Italy]] ([[Dorothea Wierer]], [[Karin Oberhofer]], [[Dominik Windisch]] and [[Lukas Hofer]]) finished third at 58.2 seconds behind.<ref name="Day13-Biathlon">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/biathlon-2x6km-women-2x7-5km-men-mixed-relay | title=Biathlon - 2x6km Women + 2x7.5 km Men Mixed Relay Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * In the [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Two-woman|two-woman]] competition, the Canadian pair of [[Kaillie Humphries]] and [[Heather Moyse]] won the gold medal, finished both the third and fourth runs with the fastest times. The silver and bronze medals went to two American teams: [[Elana Meyers]] and [[Lauryn Williams]] came in second, and [[Jamie Greubel]] and [[Aja Evans]] in third.<ref name="Day13-Bobsleigh">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/bobsleigh-women-s-heat-4 | title=Bobsleigh - Women's Heat 4 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's team sprint|men's team sprint]] semifinals, the top two in each heat qualified for the final, with the fastest other six also advancing. [[Iivo Niskanen]] and [[Sami Jauhojärvi]] (Finland) finished with the fastest time, 23:26.13. Then in the final, the same pair recorded a time of 23:14.89 to win the gold medal. [[Maxim Vylegzhanin]] and [[Nikita Kriukov]] (Russia) finished second, with [[Emil Jönsson]] and [[Teodor Peterson]] (Sweden) in third.<ref name="Day13-Cross Country-Men's team sprint">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-finland-win-team-sprint | title=Finland win team sprint | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref> * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's team sprint|women's team sprint]] semifinals, the top two in each heat qualified for the final, with the fastest other six also advancing. [[Aino-Kaisa Saarinen]] and [[Kerttu Niskanen]] (Finland) finished with the fastest time, 16:42.15. Then in the final, the Norwegian pair of [[Ingvild Flugstad Østberg]] and [[Marit Bjørgen]] finished with the gold medal. Aino-Kaisa Saarinen and Kerttu Niskanen finished second, with [[Ida Ingemarsdotter]] and [[Stina Nilsson]] (Sweden) third.<ref name="Day13-Cross Country-Women's team sprint">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-marit-bjoergen-takes-norway-to-women-s-team-sprint-gold | title=Marit Bjoergen takes Norway to women's team sprint gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Semifinals ***{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}} 5–6 '''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' ***'''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 10–6 {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Semifinals ***{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} 4–6 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' ***'''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 7–5 {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}}
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * In the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles|ladies' singles]] short program, [[Yuna Kim]] (South Korea) recorded the highest score of 74.92. [[Adelina Sotnikova]] (Russia) scored 74.64, with [[Carolina Kostner]] (Italy) finishing the day third. The top 24 athletes advanced to the free skate section of the competition.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/figure-skating-ladies-short-program | title=Figure Skating Ladies Short Program Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Quarterfinals *** '''{{ih|SWE}}''' 5–0 {{ih|SLO}} *** '''{{ih|FIN}}''' 3–1 {{ih|RUS}} *** '''{{ih|CAN}}''' 2–1 {{ih|LAT}} *** '''{{ih|USA}}''' 5–2 {{ih|CZE}}
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's parallel giant slalom|men's parallel giant slalom]], [[Andrey Sobolev]] and [[Vic Wild]] (both Russia) posted the fastest two combined times in qualification round, with the top sixteen athletes qualifying for the elimination round. The closest two races in the 1/8 finals and quarterfinals were both won by [[Nevin Galmarini]] (Switzerland), who beat [[Benjamin Karl]] (Austria) by 0.10 seconds, and [[Rok Marguč]] (Slovenia) by 0.09 seconds, respectively. But Wild beat Galmarini in the gold medal final by 2.14 seconds. Meanwhile, [[Žan Košir]] (Slovenia) beat [[Patrick Bussler]] (Germany) by 2.26 seconds in the bronze medal final.<ref name="Day13-Snowboarding-Men's PGS">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-men-s-pgs-finals | title=Men's Parallel Giant Slalom Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref> * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's parallel giant slalom|women's parallel giant slalom]], [[Tomoka Takeuchi]] (Japan) and [[Patrizia Kummer]] (Switzerland) finished with the fastest two combined times in qualification round, with the top sixteen athletes qualifying for the elimination rounds. In the 1/8 finals, the closest race was between [[Ekaterina Ilyukhina]] (Russia) and [[Caroline Calvé]] (Canada), with the latter winning by 0.03 seconds. In the semifinals, [[Ina Meschik]] (Austria) and [[Alena Zavarzina]] (Russia) were both disqualified from their respective races; Zavarzina then beat Meschik in the bronze medal final. In the gold medal final, Patrizia Kummer beat Tomoka Takeuchi by 7.32 seconds.<ref name="Day13-Snowboarding-Women's PGS">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-family-triumph-in-the-parallel-giant-slalom | title=Family triumph in the parallel giant slalom | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref> * With [[Alena Zavarzina]] winning the bronze medal in the women's competition, and [[Vic Wild]] winning gold in his race, it meant that a married couple both won medals on the same day, within a few minutes of each other.<ref>http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=11206086 Sochi: Husband and wife win medals minutes apart</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * In the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 5000 metres|women's 5000 metres]], [[Martina Sáblíková]] (Czech Republic) captured the gold, setting a new track record of 6:51.54. [[Ireen Wüst]] and [[Carien Kleibeuker]] (both of the Netherlands) finished second and third, respectively.<ref name="Day13-Speed Skating">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-martina-sablikova-wins-women-s-5-000m-speed-skate | title=Martina Sablikova wins women's 5,000m speed skate | work=Sochi 2014 | date=19 February 2014 | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>

==Day 14 – Thursday 20 February== ;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Bronze medal game ***'''{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}}''' 6–5 {{flagIOC|SUI|2014 Winter}} ***:In the 10th end, [[Eve Muirhead]]'s last shot landed on button to give Great Britain the one-point victory.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-the-british-women-s-curling-team-won-the-bronze-medal-at-the-games-in-sochi | title=The British women's curling team won the bronze medal at the Games in Sochi | work=Sochi 2014 | date=20 February 2014 | accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> ** Gold medal game ***'''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' 6–3 {{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}} ***:Canada completed the tournament undefeated, as they stole the 9th end for two points after Sweden's [[Maria Prytz]]'s final shot bumped her own team's stone out of the button. Canada then took out enough of Sweden's stones in the 10th end to force their opponents to concede the game.<ref name="Day14-Curling"/>
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * In the [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles|ladies' singles]], [[Adelina Sotnikova]] became the first Russian woman to win an Olympic gold medal in figure skating, leading the free program with 149.95 points and 224.59 overall. [[Yuna Kim]] of South Korea took the silver after recording 144.19 points in the free program and 219.11 overall. Italy's [[Carolina Kostner]] finished with the bronze at 74.12 in the free program and 216.73 overall.<ref name="Day14-Figure skating"/>
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * All three medals in the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's ski cross|men's ski cross]] went to France: [[Jean-Frédéric Chapuis]] finished first in the final to take the gold, [[Arnaud Bovolenta]] won the silver, and [[Jonathan Midol]] received the bronze. The day began with the seeding round, where [[Victor Öhling Norberg]] of Sweden recorded the fastest time of 1:15.59. The 32 seeds then competed in four-person elimination races, with the top two from each race advancing to the next round.<ref name="Day14-Freestyle skiing-Men's ski cross"/> * In the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|women's halfpipe]], [[Maddie Bowman]] (USA) won the gold medal with a score of 89.00 in the final round. [[Marie Martinod]] (France) finished second at 85.40, with [[Ayana Onozuka]] (Japan) in third at 83.20. The day began with the qualification round, where the top twelve athletes advanced to the final; Martinod finished the qualification in first place with a score of 88.40 in the second run.<ref name="Day14-Freestyle skiing-Women's halfpipe"/>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]] ** Bronze medal game ***'''{{ihw|SUI}}''' 4–3 {{ihw|SWE}} ***:Switzerland overcame a two-goal deficit, scoring four straight goals in the third period.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-switzerland-beat-sweden-4-3-to-win-women-s-ice-hockey-bronze | title=Switzerland beat Sweden 4-3 to win women's ice hockey bronze | work=Sochi 2014 | date=20 February 2014 | accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> ** Gold medal game *** '''{{ihw|CAN}}''' 3–2 (OT) {{ihw|USA}} ***:Canada scored two goals in the final 3:26 of regulation to force overtime. [[Marie-Philip Poulin]] then scored the game-winner 8:10 into the extra period.<ref name="Day14-Ice hockey"/>
;[[Image:Nordic combined pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] * In the [[Nordic combined at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Team large hill/4 × 5 km|team large hill/4 × 5 km]], the Norwegian team of [[Magnus Moan]], [[Magnus Krog]], [[Jørgen Graabak]] and [[Håvard Klemetsen]] led the cross-country section with a time of 46:48.5, and recorded 47:13.5 overall, to win the gold medal. Germany ([[Fabian Rießle]], [[Björn Kircheisen]], [[Johannes Rydzek]] and [[Eric Frenzel]]) led the ski jumping section with 481.7 points, but fell to 0.3 seconds behind overall to take the silver. Austria ([[Lukas Klapfer]], [[Christoph Bieler]], [[Mario Stecher]], [[Bernhard Gruber]]) won the bronze.<ref name="Day14-Nordic combined"/>

2014 | accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> |- |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|Women's halfpipe]] |[[Maddie Bowman]] |{{flagIOC|USA|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day14-Freestyle skiing-Women's halfpipe">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/freestyle-skiing-ladies-ski-halfpipe-final | title=Freestyle Skiing - Ladies' Ski Halfpipe Results | tournament|Women's tournament]] | [[Template:2014 Winter Olympics Canada women's ice hockey team roster|Canada women's team]] |{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day14-Ice hockey">{{cite web | large hill/4 × 5 km|Team large hill/4 × 5 km]] |[[Magnus Moan]]<br>[[Magnus Krog]]<br>[[Jørgen Graabak]]<br>[[Håvard Klemetsen]] |{{flagIOC|NOR|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day14-Nordic combined">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-norwegian-athletes-took-gold-in-the-nordic-combined-team-competitions | title=Norwegian athletes took gold in the Nordic combined team competitions | work=Sochi 2014 | date=20 February 2014 | accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> |}
==Day 15 – Friday 21 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * In the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's slalom|women's slalom]], [[Mikaela Shiffrin]] of the United States captured the gold medal, finishing with the best time in the first run at 51.92, and 1:44.54 overall. Austria's [[Marlies Schild]] had the best time in the second run at 51.11, but ended up 0.53 behind overall to finish with the silver. The bronze went to [[Kathrin Zettel]] of Austria.<ref name="Day15-Alpine Skiing">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/alpine-skiing-ladies-slalom-2nd-run | title=Alpine Skiing - Women's Slalom Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * In the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's relay|women's relay]], the Ukrainian team of [[Vita Semerenko]], [[Juliya Dzhyma]], [[Valj Semerenko]] and [[Olena Pidhrushna]] finished first with a time of 1:10:02.5. Russia ([[Yana Romanova]], [[Olga Zaitseva]], [[Ekaterina Shumilova]], [[Olga Vilukhina]]) was 26.4 seconds behind to capture the silver. Norway ([[Fanny Horn Birkeland|Fanny Welle-Strand Horn]], [[Tiril Eckhoff]], [[Ann Kristin Flatland|Ann Kristin Aafeldt Flatland]], [[Tora Berger]]) won the bronze.<ref name="Day15-Biathlon">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-ukraine-takes-gold-in-sochi | title=Ukraine takes gold in Sochi | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Curling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * [[Curling at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Bronze medal game ***'''{{flagIOC|SWE|2014 Winter}}''' 6–4 {{flagIOC|CHN|2014 Winter}} ***:Sweden tied the game in the 10th end following a close measurement to force an 11th end, then scored two points in the extra end after China's last shot failed to bump Sweden's stone out of the button.<ref name="Day15-Curling"/> ** Gold medal game ***{{flagIOC|GBR|2014 Winter}} 3–9 '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}}''' ***:Canada won their third consecutive gold medal in men's curling, scoring three points in the 3rd end, and eventually extending their lead to six points in the 8th end to force Great Britain to concede.<ref name="Day15-Curling">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-canada-win-third-successive-men-s-curling-gold | title=Canada win third successive men's curling gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * [[Marielle Thompson]] (Canada) finished first in the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's ski cross|women's ski cross]] final to take the gold, [[Kelsey Serwa]] (Canada) won the silver, and [[Anna Holmlund]] (Sweden) received the bronze. The day began with the seeding round, where Serwa recorded the fastest time of 1:21.45. The 32 seeds then competed in four-person elimination races, with the top two from each race advancing to the next round.<ref name="Day15-Freestyle skiing">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-canadian-freestylers-claimed-gold-and-silver-in-ladies-ski-cross | title=Canadian freestylers claimed gold and silver in ladies’ ski cross | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=21 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Final round – Semifinals *** '''{{ih|SWE}}''' 2–1 {{ih|FIN}} *** {{ih|USA}} 0–1 '''{{ih|CAN}}'''
;[[Image:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * In the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|women's 1000 metres]], [[Park Seung-hi]] of South Korea finished Final A (medal round) with a time of 1:30.761 to win the gold medal. [[Fan Kexin]] of China earned the silver at 1:30.811 and [[Shim Suk-hee]] of South Korea got the bronze at 1:31.027. The day began with the quarterfinals, where the top two from each of the four races advanced to the semifinals; the fastest time was recorded by [[Valérie Maltais]] (Canada) in heat two, at 1:29.037. The top two in each semifinal then advanced to Final A, with the others competing in classification round Final B. Park Seung-hi recorded the best time (1:30:202) in the semifinals. [[Jorien ter Mors]] (Netherland) won Final B with a time of 1:36.835 to finish 5th overall.<ref name="Day15-Short track-Women's 1000m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/short-track-ladies-1000-m-finals | title=Short Track-Ladies 1000 m Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> * The [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500 metres]] gold medal went to Russia's [[Victor Ahn]], [[Wu Dajing]] of China took the silver, and [[Charle Cournoyer]] of Canada received the bronze. At the start of the day, the fastest time in the quarterfinals came from Wu Dajing, with eight athletes advancing to the semifinals overall. The first semifinal was then won by Wu Dajing, with Viktor Ahn winning the second semifinal. The top two in each semifinal then advanced to the medal round. [[Liang Wenhao]] of China finished last the medal round, thus falling to fourth place overall.<ref name="Day15-Short track-Men's 500m">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-victor-ahn-victorious-again-in-500m-short-track-gold | title=Victor Ahn victorious again in 500m short track gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> * In the [[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metre relay|men's 5000 metre relay]], the Russian team of [[Viktor Ahn]], [[Semen Elistratov]], [[Vladimir Grigorev]], and [[Ruslan Zakharov]] won the gold medal, setting an Olympic record of 6:42.100 in the medal round. This was preceded by them posting the best time in the semifinals at 6:44.331. The United States ([[Eddy Alvarez]], [[J. R. Celski]], [[Chris Creveling]], [[Jordan Malone]]) won the silver. And the bronze went to [[Chen Dequan]], [[Han Tianyu]], [[Shi Jingnan]], and [[Wu Dajing]] of China.<ref name="Day15-Short track-Men's 5000m relay">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-ahn-leads-russia-to-5-000m-short-track-relay-gold | title=Ahn leads Russia to 5,000m short track relay gold | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's team pursuit|men's team pursuit]] quarterfinals and semifinals were held, setting up a gold medal final between the Netherlands and South Korea, and a bronze medal final between Poland and Canada. The best time recorded during the day was the Netherlands, who finished at 3:40.79 to defeat Poland in the semifinals.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/speed-skating-men-s-team-pursuit-semifinals | title=Speed Skating-Men's Team Pursuit Semifinals Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> * The [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's team pursuit|women's team pursuit]] quarterfinals were held. The Netherlands, Japan, Russia and Poland advanced to the semifinals. The best time recorded during the day was the Netherlands, who set an Olympic record of 2:58.61 to defeat the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/speed-skating-ladies-team-pursuit-quarterfinals | title=Speed Skating-Ladies Team Pursuit Quarterfinals Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=21 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>

Harnden]]<br>[[Ryan Harnden]]<br>[[Caleb Flaxey]] |{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day15-Curling"/> |- |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] |[[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's ski cross|Women's ski cross]] |[[Marielle Thompson]] |{{flagIOC|CAN|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day15-Freestyle skiing"/> |- |rowspan=3|[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] |[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|Women's 1000 metres]] |[[Park Seung-hi]] |{{flagIOC|KOR|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day15-Short track-Women's 1000m"/> |- |[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|Men's 500 metres]] |[[Viktor Ahn]] |{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} | |<ref name="Day15-Short track-Men's 500m"/> |- |[[Short track speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metre relay|Men's 5000 metre relay]] |[[Viktor Ahn]]<br>[[Semen Elistratov]]<br>[[Vladimir Grigorev]]<br>[[Ruslan Zakharov]] |{{flagIOC|RUS|2014 Winter}} |[[List of Olympic records in short track speed skating|OR]] |<ref name="Day15-Short track-Men's 5000m relay"/> |}
==Day 16 – Saturday 22 February== ;[[Image:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * In the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's slalom|men's slalom]], [[Mario Matt]] (Austria) recorded the best time in the first run, 46.70, as well as the best overall time of 1:41.84 to win the gold medal. Austria's [[Marcel Hirscher]] finished 0.28 behind overall to win the silver, and [[Henrik Kristoffersen]] (Norway) was 0.83 behind to get the bronze. [[Adam Žampa]] of Slovakia recorded the best time in the second run, 1:43.28, but ended up in sixth place overall.<ref name="Day16-Alpine Skiing">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/alpine-skiing-men-s-slalom-2nd-run | title=Alpine Skiing - Men's Slalom Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The IOC announced that [[Evi Sachenbacher-Stehle]] of Germany tested positive for the banned stimulant [[methylhexanamine]], and thus stripped her fourth-place finish in the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's mass start|women's mass start]], as well as the German team's fourth-place result in the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Mixed relay|mixed relay]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/winter-olympics/26289156 |title=Sochi 2014: Evi Sachenbacher-Stehle and William Frullani sent home |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 February 2014}}</ref> * The gold medal in the [[Biathlon at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's relay|men's relay]] was won by the Russian team of [[Alexey Volkov (biathlete)|Alexey Volkov]], [[Evgeny Ustyugov]], [[Dmitry Malyshko]] and [[Anton Shipulin]] with a time of 1:12:15.9. Germany ([[Erik Lesser]], [[Daniel Böhm]], [[Arnd Peiffer]], [[Simon Schempp]]) was 3.5 seconds behind to take the silver, and the bronze went to Austria ([[Christoph Sumann]], [[Daniel Mesotitsch]], [[Simon Eder]], [[Dominik Landertinger]]) at 29.8 seconds behind.<ref name="Day16-Biathlon">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-russia-took-gold-in-a-men-s-team-relay | title=Russia took gold in a men's team relay | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The first two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Four-man|four-man]] were held. In the first run, the Russian team of [[Alexandr Zubkov]], [[Dmitry Trunenkov]], [[Alexey Negodaylo]] and [[Alexey Voyevoda]] set a track record of 54.82.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/bobsleigh-four-man-heat-1 | title=Bobsleigh - Four-man Heat 1 Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * All three medals in the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 30 kilometre freestyle|women's 30 km freestyle]] went to Norway. [[Marit Bjørgen]] received the gold with a time of 1:11:05.2, [[Therese Johaug]] finished second at 2.6 back, and [[Kristin Størmer Steira]] finished third at 23.6 back.<ref name="Day16-Cross Country">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/cross-country-ladies-30-km-free-mass-start | title=Cross Country - Ladies 30km Free Mass Start Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The exhibition gala was held. The {{frac|2|1|2}}-hour show had performances by all individual gold medalists and many others.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilner|first=Barry|title=Rock, Classical, Broadway at Sochi Gala Skate|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/rock-classical-broadway-sochi-gala-skate-22633193|publisher=ABC News|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=23 February 2014|date=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Bronze medal game *** {{ih|USA}} 0–5 '''{{ih|FIN}}''' ***:Finland scored two goals 11 seconds apart in the second period, and then three successive goals in the third period. Goaltender [[Tuukka Rask]] stopped all 27 American shots.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/ice-hockey-men-s-bronze-medal-game-02 | title=Ice Hockey - Men's Bronze Medal Game | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's parallel slalom|men's parallel slalom]], [[Vic Wild]] of Russia beat [[Žan Košir]] of Sovenia in the gold medal final by a difference of 0.11. The bronze medal final was won by [[Benjamin Karl]], who beat Italy's [[Aaron March]]. The day began with the qualification round, with Vic Wild recording the fastest time at 57.96. The top 16 then advanced to the four round elimination tournament.<ref name="Day16-Snowboarding-Mens">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-men-s-psl-finals | title=Snowboard - Men's Parallel Slalom Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's parallel slalom|women's parallel slalom]], Austria's [[Julia Dujmovits]] beat Germany's [[Anke Karstens]] in the gold medal final by a difference of 0.12. And [[Amelie Kober]] of Germany beat Italy's [[Corinna Boccacini]] in the bronze medal final. The day began with the qualification round, with [[Marion Kreiner]] (Austria) recording the fastest time at 1:03.58. The top 16 then advanced to the four round elimination tournament.<ref name="Day16-Snowboarding-Womens">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/snowboard-ladies-psl-finals | title=Snowboard - Women's Parallel Slalom Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * In the gold medal final of the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's team pursuit|men's team pursuit]], [[Jan Blokhuijsen]], [[Sven Kramer]] and [[Koen Verweij]] of the Netherlands set an Olympic record of 3:37.71. The South Korean team of [[Joo Hyong-jun]], [[Kim Cheol-min]] and [[Lee Seung-hoon]] was 3.14 behind to win the silver. In the bronze medal final, Poland ([[Zbigniew Bródka]], [[Konrad Niedźwiedzki]] and [[Jan Szymański (speed skater)|Jan Szymański]]) beat Canada ([[Mathieu Giroux]], [[Lucas Makowsky]] and [[Denny Morrison]]) by 2.33.<ref name="Day16-Speed Skating-Mens">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/speed-skating-men-s-team-pursuit-finals | title=Speed Skating - Men's Team Pursuit Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> * In the [[Speed skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's team pursuit|women's team pursuit]] semifinals and finals, the Dutch team of [[Jorien ter Mors]], [[Marrit Leenstra (speed skater)|Marrit Leenstra]], [[Ireen Wüst]] and [[Lotte van Beek]] set Olympic records on their way to winning the gold. They first set the record in the semifinals with a time of 2:58.43 to beat Japan ([[Misaki Oshigiri]], [[Maki Tabata]] and [[Nana Takagi]]). The Netherlands then broke the record again with a time of 2:58.05 in the final. Poland was 7.50 behind in the final to win the silver. Russia ([[Olga Graf]], [[Yekaterina Lobysheva]] and [[Yuliya Skokova]]) then beat Japan to win the bronze.<ref name="Day16-Speed Skating-Womens">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/speed-skating-ladies-team-pursuit-finals | title=Speed Skating - Women's Team Pursuit Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=22 February 2014 | accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>

==Day 17 – Sunday 23 February== ;[[Image:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The final two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Four-man|four-man event]] were held. The Russian team of [[Alexandr Zubkov]], [[Dmitry Trunenkov]], [[Alexey Negodaylo]] and [[Alexey Voyevoda]] won the gold, recording the best time in the third run, 55.02, as well as the best overall time of 3:40.60. Latvia ([[Oskars Melbārdis]], [[Arvis Vilkaste]], [[Daumants Dreiškens]] and [[Jānis Strenga]]) finished with the silver, 0.09 seconds behind Russia overall. The United States ([[Steven Holcomb]], [[Steven Langton]], [[Curtis Tomasevicz]] and [[Christopher Fogt]]) took the bronze, 0.39 seconds behind. The best time recorded in the fourth run was 55.21 by the second Russian team ([[Alexander Kasjanov]], [[Maxim Belugin]], [[Ilvir Huzin]] and [[Aleksei Pushkarev]]), but they finished fourth overall.<ref name="Day17-Bobsleigh">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/bobsleigh-four-man-heat-4 | title=Bobsleigh - Men's Four Man Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=23 February 2014 | accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The medals in the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's 50 kilometre freestyle|men's 50 km freestyle]] all went to Russia. [[Alexander Legkov]] finished the race at 1:46:55.2 to win the gold. A [[photo finish]] determined that [[Maxim Vylegzhanin]] finished in second, 0.7 seconds behind, and [[Ilia Chernousov]] was third, 0.8 seconds behind the leader.<ref name="Day17-Cross Country">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/cross-country-men-s-50-km-free-mass-start | title=Cross Country - Men's 50 km Mass Start Free Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=23 February 2014 | accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[Image:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]] ** Gold medal game *** {{ih|SWE}} 0–3 '''{{ih|CAN}}''' ***: Canada got goals from three different players. Goaltender [[Carey Price]] stopped all 24 Swedish shots.<ref name="Day17-Ice Hockey">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/ice-hockey-men-s-gold-medal-game-01 | title=Ice Hockey - Men's Gold Medal Game Results | work=Sochi 2014 | date=23 February 2014 | accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref>
;[[File:Olympic Rings Icon.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[2014 Winter Olympics closing ceremony|Closing ceremony]] * The closing ceremony began at 20:14 [[Moscow Time|MSK]] at [[Fisht Olympic Stadium]]. It featured the traditional elements of Olympic closing ceremonies such as the parade of flags and athletes; the handover ceremony to the site of [[2018 Winter Olympics|the next Winter Olympics]], [[Pyeongchang County|Pyeongchang]], [[South Korea]]; and the extinguishing of the Olympic flame. During the ceremony, Russia poked fun at the opening ceremony, where one of the Olympic rings did not open; the fifth group of dancers representing the rings took longer than the others to open. It did eventually open, to cheers from the Russian audience.<ref name="Day17-Closing ceremony">{{cite web | url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/news-sochi-2014-closing-ceremony-unites-olympic-generations | title=Sochi 2014 Closing Ceremony Unites Olympic Generations | work=Sochi 2014 | date=23 February 2014 | accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref>

{{more citations needed|date=October 2014}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Chronology of computation of {{pi}}}} The table below is a brief chronology of computed numerical values of, or bounds on, the mathematical constant [[pi]] ({{pi}}). For more detailed explanations for some of these calculations, see [[Approximations of π|Approximations of {{pi}}]]. [[File:Record pi approximations.svg|thumb|center|800px|Graph showing how the record precision of numerical approximations to pi measured in decimal places (depicted on a logarithmic scale), evolved in human history. The time before 1400 is compressed.]] {{clear}} == Before 1400 == {| class="wikitable" |- !align="left"| Date !align="left"| Who !align="left"| Description/Computation method used !align="right"| Value of pi !align="right"| Decimal places
([[world record]]s
in '''bold''') |- |2000? BCЕ|| |4 × (8 / 9)2 |align="right"|3.16045...||'''1''' |- |2000? BCЕ||Ancient Babylonians{{cite journal|authors=David H. Bailey, Jonathan M. Borwein, Peter B. Borwein & Simon Plouffe|year=1997|title=The quest for pi|url=http://crd-legacy.lbl.gov/~dhbailey/dhbpapers/pi-quest.pdf|journal=[[Mathematical Intelligencer]]|volume=19|issue=1|pages=50–57}} |3 + 1 / 8||align="right"|3.125||1 |- |1800? BCE or before|| Ancient Indians (Bharatiya) शतपथ ब्राह्मण SB 7.1.1.18 http://mduchin.math.tufts.edu/UCD/111/readings/kak1.pdf ||"स चतस्रः प्राचीरुपदधाति | द्वे पश्चात्तिरश्च्यौ द्वे पुरस्तात्तद्याश्चतस्रः प्राचीरुपदधाति स आत्मा तद्यत्ताश्चतस्रो भवन्ति चतुर्विधो ह्ययमात्माथ ये पश्चात्ते सक्थ्यौ ये पुरस्तात्तौ बाहू यत्र वा आत्मा तदेव शिरः sa catasraḥ prācīrupadadhāti | dve paścāttiraścyau dve purastāttadyāścatasraḥ prācīrupadadhāti sa ātmā tadyattāścatasro bhavanti caturvidho hyayamātmātha ye paścātte sakthyau ye purastāttau bāhū yatra vā ātmā tadeva śiraḥ He puts on (the circular site) four (bricks) running eastwards 1; two behind running crosswise (from south to north), and two (such) in front. Now the four which he puts on running eastwards are the body; and as to there being four of these, it is because this body (of ours) consists, of four parts 2. The two at the back then are the thighs; and the two in front the arms; and where the body is that (includes) the head."{{cite book|title=The Sacred Books of the East: The Satapatha-Brahmana, pt. 3|year=1894|publisher=Clarendon Press|page=303}} {{PD-notice}} |align="right"|25/8 = 3.125|| |- |1200? BCЕ||China |||align="right"|3||0 |- |800? BCЕ||[[Sulbasutras]] http://www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/Projects/Pearce/Chapters/Ch4_2.html {{cite journal |authors=Ravi P. Agarwal, Hans Agarwal & Syamal K. |align="right"|3.1415926||'''7''' |- |499||[[Aryabhata]] |62832 / 20000 |align="right"|3.1416||3 |- |640||[[Brahmagupta]] |{{radic|10}} |align="right"|3.162277...||1 |- |800||[[Al Khwarizmi]] | |align="right"|3.1416||3 |- |1150||[[Bhāskara II]] | 3927 / 1250 and 754 / 240 |align="right"|3.1416||3 |- |1220||[[Leonardo of Pisa|Fibonacci]] | |align="right"|3.141818||3 |- |1320|| [[Zhao Youqin's π algorithm|Zhao Youqin]] | |align="right"|3.1415926||7 |} == From 1400 onwards == {| class="wikitable" |- !align="left"| Date !align="left"| Who !align="left"| Note !align="right"| Decimal places

16 |- |1699||[[Abraham Sharp]] |Calculated pi to 72 digits, but not all were correct |align="right"|'''71''' |- |1706||[[John Machin]] | |align="right"|'''100''' |- |1706||[[William Jones (mathematician)|William Jones]] |Introduced the Greek letter '[[Pi (letter)|{{pi}}]]' | |- |1719||[[Thomas Fantet de Lagny]] |Calculated 127 decimal places, but not all were correct |align="right"|'''112''' |- |1722||[[Toshikiyo Kamata]] | |align="right"|24 |- |1722||[[Takebe Kenko|Katahiro Takebe]] | |align="right"|41 |- |1739||[[Yoshisuke Matsunaga]] | |align="right"|51 |- |1748||[[Leonhard Euler]] |Used the Greek letter '{{pi}}' in his book ''Introductio in Analysin Infinitorum'' and assured its popularity. | |- |1761||[[Johann Heinrich Lambert]] |Proved that {{pi}} is [[irrational number|irrational]] | |- |1775||Euler |Pointed out the possibility that {{pi}} might be [[transcendental number|transcendental]] | |- |1789||[[Jurij Vega]] |Calculated 143 decimal places, but not all were correct |align="right"|'''126''' |- |1794||[[Jurij Vega]] |Calculated 140 decimal places, but not all were correct |align="right"|'''136''' |- |1794||[[Adrien-Marie Legendre]] |Showed that {{pi}}² (and hence {{pi}}) is irrational, and mentioned the possibility that {{pi}} might be transcendental. | |- |Late 18th century||Anonymous manuscript |Turns up at Radcliffe Library, in Oxford, England, discovered by F. X. von Zach, giving the value of pi to 154 digits, 152 of which were correct |align="right"|'''152''' |- |1824||[[William Rutherford (mathematician)|William Rutherford]] |Calculated 208 decimal places, but not all were correct |align="right"|152 |- |1844||[[Zacharias Dase]] and Strassnitzky |Calculated 205 decimal places, but not all were correct |align="right"|'''200''' |- |1847||[[Thomas Clausen (mathematician)|Thomas Clausen]] |Calculated 250 decimal places, but not all were correct |align="right"|'''248''' |- |1853||Lehmann | |align="right"|'''261''' |- |1853||Rutherford | |align="right"|'''440''' |- |1874||[[William Shanks]] |Took 15 years to calculate 707 decimal places, but not all were correct (the error was found by D. F. Ferguson in 1946) |align="right"|'''527''' |- |1882||[[Ferdinand von Lindemann]] |Proved that {{pi}} is [[Transcendental numbers|transcendental]] (the [[Lindemann–Weierstrass theorem]]) | |- |1897||The U.S. state of [[Indiana]] |Came close to legislating the value 3.2 (among others) for {{pi}}. [[Indiana Pi Bill|House Bill No. 246]] passed unanimously. The bill stalled in the state Senate due to a suggestion of possible commercial motives involving publication of a textbook.{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.uu.nl/wais/html/na-dir/sci-math-faq/indianabill.html|title=Indiana Bill sets value of Pi to 3|last=Lopez-Ortiz |first=Alex|date=February 20, 1998 |work=the news.answers WWW archive|publisher=Department of Information and Computing Sciences, Utrecht University|accessdate=2009-02-01}} |align="right"|{{color|red|1}} |- |1910||[[Srinivasa Ramanujan]] |Found several rapidly converging infinite series of {{pi}}, which can compute 8 decimal places of {{pi}} with each term in the series. drive) – Hitachi (HDS721010CLA332), 3 × 2 TB SATA II (Store Pi Output) – Seagate (ST32000542AS) 16 x 2 TB SATA II (Computation) – Seagate (ST32000641AS) * Windows Server 2008 R2 Enterprise x64 * Computation of binary digits: 80 days * Conversion to base 10: 8.2 days * Verification of the conversion: 45.6 hours * Verification of the binary digits: 64 hours (primary), 66 hours (secondary) * Verification of the binary digits were done simultaneously on two separate computers during the main computation.{{cite web|url=http://www.numberworld.org/misc_runs/pi-5t/announce_en.html|title=Pi – 5 Trillion Digits|author=|date=|work=numberworld.org|accessdate=28 August 2015}} |90 days |align="right"|'''5,000,000,000,000''' |- |17 October 2011 |Shigeru Kondo{{cite web|url=http://www.numberworld.org/misc_runs/pi-10t/details.html|title=Pi – 10 Trillion Digits|author=|date=|work=numberworld.org|accessdate=28 August 2015}} | * using y-cruncher by Alexander Yee * Verification: 1.86 days and 4.94 days |371 days |align="right"|'''10,000,000,000,050''' |- |28 December 2013 |Shigeru Kondo{{cite web|url=http://www.numberworld.org/misc_runs/pi-12t/|title=Pi – 12.1 Trillion Digits|author=|date=|work=numberworld.org|accessdate=28 August 2015}} | * using y-cruncher by Alexander Yee * with 2 x Intel Xeon E5-2690 @ 2.9 GHz – (16 physical cores, 32 hyperthreaded) * 128 GB DDR3 @ 1600 MHz – 8 x 16 GB – 8 channels * Windows Server 2012 x64 * Verification: 46 hours |94 days |align="right"|'''12,100,000,000,050''' |- |8 October 2014 |Sandon Nash Van Ness "houkouonchi"{{cite web|url=http://www.numberworld.org/y-cruncher/|title=y-cruncher – A Multi-Threaded Pi Program|author=|date=|work=numberworld.org|accessdate=14 March 2018}} | * using y-cruncher by Alexander Yee * with 2 x Xeon E5-4650L @ 2.6 GHz * 192 GB DDR3 @ 1333 MHz * 24 x 4 TB + 30 x 3 TB * Verification: 182 hours |208 days |align="right"|'''13,300,000,000,000''' |- |11 November 2016 |Peter Trueb{{cite web|url=http://pi2e.ch/|title=pi2e|author=|date=|work=pi2e.ch|accessdate=15 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.numberworld.org/y-cruncher/|title=y-cruncher – A Multi-Threaded Pi Program|author=|date=|work=numberworld.org|accessdate=15 November 2016}} | * using y-cruncher by Alexander Yee * with 4 x Xeon E7-8890 v3 @ 2.50 GHz (72 cores, 144 threads) * 1.25 TB DDR4 * 20 x 6 TB * Verification: 28 hours{{cite web|url=http://pi2e.ch/blog/2016/10/31/hexadecimal-digits-are-correct/|title=Hexadecimal Digits are Correct! – pi2e trillion digits of pi|author=|date=|work=pi2e.ch|accessdate=15 November 2016}} |105 days |align="right"|'''22,459,157,718,361'''22,459,157,718,361 is {{pi}}e × 1012 rounded down. |} ==See also== * [[History of pi]] {{Pi
