revision.text:
'''''The Kilroys' List'''''<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://thekilroys.org|title = The Kilroys|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> is a ''[[The Kilroys' List#Gender Parity|gender parity]]'' initiative to end the "systematic underrepresentation of female and [[Transgender|trans]] playwrights" in the American theater industry.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = The Kilroys|url = http://thekilroys.org|website = The Kilroys|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> ''Gender disparity'' is defined as the gap of unproduced playwrights' whose plays are being discriminated against based on the writer's gender identification and [[Intersectionality|intersectional]] identities of race, sexual orientation, ethnicity, socioeconomic class, age, and ability. [[The Kilroys' List#Statistical Research and Analysis|Recent statistical research]] released in November 2015, entitled ''The Count'', gathered that 22% of total surveyed professional productions from 2011-2013 annual seasons were written by women playwrights, 3.8% of the total were written by women playwrights of color, and 0.4% of the total were written by foreign women playwrights of color.<ref name=":4" /> 78% of total surveyed professional productions were written by men playwrights.<ref name=":4" />
First released in June 2014, The list is an annual collection of highly recommended contemporary plays written by female and [[Transgender|trans*]] identified authors, which are read or seen by an industry professional within the last twelve months. The list was established by ''The Kilroys'', a group of Los Angeles-based female-identified playwrights and producers who were tired of their plays remaining unproduced while artistic directors claimed "We chose the best plays" for their theater companies' annual seasons.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Kilroys Were Here: Moving Female Playwrights into Production|url = http://howlround.com/the-kilroys-were-here-moving-female-playwrights-into-production|website = HowlRound|accessdate = 2015-11-18}}</ref> The namesake of ''The Kilroys'' originated from the World War II graffiti tag, "[[Kilroy was here|Kilroy Was Here]]."<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|title = Group Called the Kilroys Releases List of Plays by Women|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/17/theater/call-for-theaters-to-produce-more-plays-by-women.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2014-06-16|access-date = 2015-10-26|issn = 0362-4331|first = Patrick|last = Healy}}</ref> The tagline for ''The Kilroys'' is "We Make Trouble and Plays."<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Kilroys|url = http://thekilroys.org|website = The Kilroys|accessdate = 2015-11-11}}</ref> The Kilroys members include: Zakiyyah Alexander,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/2963/zakiyyah-alexander|title = Zakiyyah Alexander|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> Bekah Brunstetter, [[Sheila Callaghan]],<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/166/sheila-callaghan|title = Sheila Callaghan|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> Carla Ching,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/1906/carla-ching|title = Carla Ching|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> Annah Feinberg,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/927/annah-feinberg|title = Annah Feinberg|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> Sarah Gubbins,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/2962/sarah-gubbins|title = Sarah Gubbins|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> Laura Jacqmin,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/634/laura-jacqmin|title = Laura Jacqmin|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> Joy Meads, Kelly Miller, Meg Miroshnik,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/3174/meg-miroshnik|title = Meg Miroshnik|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> Daria Polatin, Tanya Saracho,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org/users/2935/tanya-saracho|title = Tanya Saracho|date = |accessdate = |website = New Play Exchange|publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> and [[Marisa Wegrzyn]].
In 2014 the list featured the Top 46, a collection of 46 plays highly recommended by selected Nominators. The Nominators consisted of a number of contemporary theater artists and administrators currently working in the theater industry.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Group Called the Kilroys Releases List of Plays by Women|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/17/theater/call-for-theaters-to-produce-more-plays-by-women.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2014-06-16|access-date = 2015-11-11|issn = 0362-4331|first = Patrick|last = Healy}}</ref>
The 2015 List: The top 7% featured 53 plays.
== Eligibility == To qualify as eligible for The List, a play must be: * "unproduced or have had only a single professional production"<ref>{{Cite web|title = About The List|url = http://thekilroys.org/list/|website = The Kilroys|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> * written by a playwright who self-identifies as female or trans* * read or seen by an industry professional in the past twelve months * not included in the in previous years
== Gender parity == Gender Parity is a term that has grown to widespread popularity in the theater industry in recent years. There have been several initiatives started to address the underrepresentation of, and discrimination against, women and [[Transgender|trans*]] artists and administrators.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|title = International Centre for Women Playwrights - Gender Equity Facts|url = http://www.womenplaywrights.org/research|website = www.womenplaywrights.org|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref> Much of this work has been statistical research based on numbers of women and [[Transgender|trans*]] artists and administrators filing roles within a theater organization's staff and theatrical season.
=== Statistical research and analysis === Considered the most recent statistical research and analysis on gender disparity, ''The Count'' was founded by playwrights and co-founders of the ''[[Lilly Awards]]'', [[Marsha Norman]] and [[Julia Jordan]], and Rebecca Stump of the [[Dramatists Guild of America|Dramatists Guild]]. This research was presented at the annual ''Lilly Awards'' in July 2015 and published in November 2015 by the |Dramatists Guild.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Dramatists Guild National Conference: #writechange - The Count - LA FPI|url = http://lafpi.com/2015/07/dramatists-guild-national-conference-writechange-the-count/|website = LA FPI|accessdate = 2015-11-09|language = en-US}}</ref>
Theaters that were eligible for survey must be not-for-profit and regional, including Off-Broadway and Off-Off Broadway.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://www.dramatistsguild.com/media/PDFs/TheCount.pdf|title = The Count|date = November–December 2015|accessdate = 2015-11-09|website = |publisher = The Dramatist|last = Norman|first = Marsha|last2 = Jordan|first2 = Julia}}</ref> Broadway theaters were not included in the survey. In total, 153 theater companies' 2011-2012, 2012-2013, and 2013-2014 seasons were included in the national survey.<ref name=":4" />
Julia Jordan has been quoted saying, "We wanted to create a baseline and to document the change."<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|title = Small Gains for Female Playwrights|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/16/theater/small-gains-for-female-playwrights.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-07-15|access-date = 2015-11-09|issn = 0362-4331|first = Cara|last = Buckley}}</ref> This baseline consists of percentage breakdowns based on the coined terms'','' "Unique Writers," which allows each individual produced writer to be counted once within the data, and "Unique Productions," which allows each individual production of a writer's play to be counted once within the data.<ref name=":4" /> For instance, while [[Lynn Nottage]] is considered a "Unique Writer," each production of her play ''[[Intimate Apparel (play)|Intimate Apparel]]'' would be considered a "Unique Production." Within these categories, ''The Count'' measured representations based on the playwright's self-identified intersections of race, gender, and nationality.<ref name=":4" /> These percentages can be seen below in ascending order of percentage: {| class="wikitable" !Unique writers by gender, race, and nationality<ref name=":4" /> |- |0.4% Foreign women of color |- |0.4% Foreign men of color |- |2.5% Foreign white women |- |3.4% American women of color |- |6.0% American men of color |- |10.6% Foreign white men |- |14.0% American white women |- |62.7% American white men |}
In addition, ''The Count'' included percentage breakdowns by a U.S. regional map and by individual city. Selected cities consisted of: {| class="wikitable" !Selected cities !Selected cities: productions of female writers !Selected cities: productions of female writers of color<ref name=":4" /> |- |Portland |18% |10.4% |- |Los Angeles |23% |17.3% |- |Minneapolis |23% |9.1% |- |Seattle |23% |4.7% |- |New York |25% |15.7% |- |Berkley |29% |11.7% |- |Philadelphia |29% |13.1% |- |Kansas City |30% |15.6% |- |Washington |30% |18.8% |- |Chicago |36% |28.4% |} The Count will continue to be updated on an annual basis.<ref name=":3" />
=== Additional gender parity initiatives === One of the first initial statistical research and analyses on ''gender disparity'' was an honors research project completed by, then Princeton undergraduate student, Emily Glassberg Sands titled, ''Opening the Curtain on Playwright Gender: An Integrated Economic Analysis of Discrimination in American Theater''.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Rethinking Gender Bias in Theater|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/24/theater/24play.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2009-06-24|access-date = 2015-11-09|issn = 0362-4331|first = Patricia|last = Cohen}}</ref>
After what has become known as "the Summit"—a gathering of artistic directors and artists in Washington D.C., when an artistic director made a controversial comment about no plays by women in the American theater industry "pipeline"—the '''We Exist''' google document was created to document the names of women and trans* identified playwrights across the world.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The New Definition Of Women Writers|url = http://thefederalist.com/2014/04/04/the-new-definition-of-women-writers/|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite web|title = The Unsung Gender-Parity Warriors|url = http://www.americantheatre.org/2015/09/21/the-unsung-gender-parity-warriors/|website = American Theatre|accessdate = 2015-11-09|first = Suzy|last = Evans}}</ref>
Other gender parity initiatives include [[Theatre Communications Group]]'s ''82 Theatre Companies With Playwriting Parity'' ''(and Better)'', published by American Theatre Magazine in September 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 82 Theatre Companies With Playwriting Parity (and Better)|url = http://www.americantheatre.org/2015/09/21/78-theatre-companies-with-playwriting-parity-and-above/|website = American Theatre|accessdate = 2015-11-09|first = Suzy|last = Evans}}</ref> In addition, there have been formations of citywide Women's Playwriting Festivals such as the 2015 ''D.C. Women's Voices Theater Festival'', which produced 56 new plays by women at 51 theaters across the greater D.C. area, and city-based Gender Parity Task Force Groups.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = We Are Part of the Problem---and of the Solution|url = http://www.americantheatre.org/2015/09/21/we-are-part-of-the-problem-and-of-the-solution/|website = AMERICAN THEATRE|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = For 44 D.C. area theater companies, new plays by women will take center stage in fall of 2015|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/theater_dance/for-44-dc-area-theater-companies-new-plays-by-women-will-take-center-stage-in-fall-of-2015/2014/01/23/7c253020-844f-11e3-a273-6ffd9cf9f4ba_story.html|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = 2014-01-23|access-date = 2015-11-09|issn = 0190-8286|language = en-US|first = Peter|last = Marks}}</ref> There has also been increased scholarship in uncovering plays by women, for instance Susan Jones's ''The Other Canon'', a list of plays by women that date back 10 centuries.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Other Canon: 10 Centuries of Plays by Women|url = http://www.americantheatre.org/2015/09/21/the-other-canon-10-centuries-of-plays-by-women/|website = American Theatre|accessdate = 2015-11-09|first = Susan|last = Jonas}}</ref>
In addition, there are annual theater awards for recognition of contemporary women playwrights such as the ''Lilly Awards'', named after playwright [[Lillian Hellman]], which was founded in 2010 by playwrights Marsha Norman, Julia Jordan]], and Theresa Rebeck]], as well as theater companies dedicated to producing work written and directed by women such as the [[Women's Project Theater]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Livestreaming The Sixth Annual Lilly Awards Ceremony—hosted by Tony Award nominee Lisa Kron—Mon, June 1—#lillyawards|url = http://howlround.com/livestreaming-the-sixth-annual-lilly-awards-ceremony-hosted-by-tony-award-nominee-lisa-kron-mon-june|website = HowlRound|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = It's All About You: The March Towards Parity in the American Theatre|last = Crosby|first = Julie|date = December 2010|journal = Theatre Journal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |publisher = Johns Hopkins University Press|issue = 4|volume = 62|pages = 571–574}}</ref>
== New Play Exchange == For the 2015 List, the ''Kilroys'' partnered with the [[National New Play Network - (NNPN)|National New Play Network]] for their online database, the New Play Exchange.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://newplayexchange.org|title = New Play Exchange|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = National New Play Network|last = |first = }}</ref> The exchange allows playwrights to create accounts to include their professional work in the form sample pages or full-length plays. The website is an initiative to address how professional theaters can use a more efficient selection process to determine which plays will be produced for their annual seasons.<ref>{{Cite web|title = American Theatre – November 2013|url = http://www.tcg.org/publications/at/issue/featuredstory.cfm?story=8&indexID=37|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117015602/http://www.tcg.org/publications/at/issue/featuredstory.cfm?story=8&indexID=37|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2015-11-17|website = www.tcg.org|accessdate = 2015-11-15}}</ref> In previous years, "There had been hundreds of conversations about how the submission model was broken, how people filled their offices and built furniture out of unread scripts, how playwrights waited for years to hear back about the plays they just knew were perfect."<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|title = Doers Gonna Do—National New Play Network & the New Play Exchange|url = http://howlround.com/doers-gonna-do-national-new-play-network-the-new-play-exchange|website = HowlRound|accessdate = 2015-11-15}}</ref>
In addition to uploading samples pages or full length pages of scripts and musical scores, playwrights can include information on casting breakdowns, keywords, and past production history. Anyone can create profiles to find playwrights, to read and privately evaluate plays, build a "private library," and "watch" others on the New Play Exchange as they add more to their profiles.<ref name=":9" /> It will serve as a "tool for students, audiences, and new play lovers everywhere to access new works. It will serve organizations so that they can let playwrights know what they are looking to read, to develop, and to produce."<ref name=":9" />
== Impact of the lists == The ''Kilroys' List'' has been covered nationwide in newspapers and other online media sources.<ref>{{Cite web|title = PRESS {{!}} The Kilroys|url = http://thekilroys.org/press/|website = The Kilroys|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref> After the 2014 list was released, the Kilroys were determined to expand the nominating pool "to increase [writer] representation along class, ability, sexual orientation, and gender lines (including genderqueer, trans*, and other non-binary gender identities)."<ref name=":6" /><ref name="artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com">{{Cite web|title = Advocates Make Another List of Plays by Women Deserving of Productions|url = http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/06/21/advocates-make-another-list-of-plays-by-women-deserving-of-productions/?_r=3|website = ArtsBeat|accessdate = 2015-11-15}}</ref>
In June 2015, American Theatre Magazine wrote, "The impact of that initial list is hard to measure precisely, particularly given the long lead times of some theatres’ season planning, but the Kilroys have reported that 28 of the original 47 plays have since been produced, and individual writers cited on the list have reported more interest and requests for their scripts, if not a spate of production commitments."<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|title = The Kilroys Make Another List of Plays by Women You Should Know|url = http://www.americantheatre.org/2015/06/22/the-kilroys-make-another-list-of-plays-by-women-you-should-know/|website = American Theatre|accessdate = 2015-11-09|first = Rob|last = Weinert-Kendt}}</ref><ref name="artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com"/> In addition, there have been publicly promoted initiatives to utilize the lists, including a reading series of 3 selected plays from the 2014 List, hosted by the ''Lilly Awards''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Kilroys Were Here (at the Lillys' Behest)|url = http://www.americantheatre.org/2015/03/18/the-kilroys-were-here-the-lillys-hosted/|website = American Theatre|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref> Also, playwright Sheila Callaghan<ref name=":8" /> is quoted in American Theatre Magazine saying, “A school is doing a class on just the Kilroys plays...That’s part of the movement, too.”<ref name=":6" />
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Theatrical organizations in the United States]] [[Category:21st-century theatre]] [[Category:2014 in theatre]] [[Category:2015 in theatre]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Virtual Revolution | image = The Virtual Revolution title.png |alt=The dark background contains the text "The Virtual Revolution" in an all-caps, sans-serif font constructed of a series of dots with lines drawn between that also construct a map of the world behind the text, indicative of the connectivity of the internet | caption = ''The Virtual Revolution'' title | show_name_2 = | genre = Technology | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = [[Aleks Krotoski]] | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_series = 1 | num_episodes = 4 | list_episodes = #Episodes | executive_producer = Dominic Crossley-Holland | producer = [[Russell Barnes]] | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 60 minutes | company = [[BBC]]
[[Open University]] | distributor = | channel = [[BBC Two]], [[BBC HD]] | picture_format = [[16:9]] [[High-definition television|HDTV]] [[1080i]] | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = {{start date|2010|1|30|df=yes}} | last_aired = 20 February 2010 | status = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/virtualrevolution/ | production_website = }} '''''The Virtual Revolution''''' is a British television [[documentary]] series presented by [[Aleks Krotoski]], which began airing on [[BBC Two]] on 30 January 2010. A co-production between the [[BBC]] and the [[Open University]], the series looks at the impact the [[World Wide Web]] has had since its inception 20 years ago. The series took a different approach to BBC documentary making by encouraging an open and collaborative production. ==Production== The series was announced on 10 July 2009, under the working title of ''Digital Revolution'', to examine the impact the [[World Wide Web]] has had on society over its first 20 years. Technology journalist and academic [[Aleks Krotoski]] would present.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/07_july/10/digital.shtml|title=BBC Two set to engage public in unique look at how the web has revolutionised our lives|date=10 July 2009|publisher=[[BBC]] Press Office|accessdate=3 February 2010}} The series was launched with an event at the BBC to mark the twentieth anniversary of the World Wide Web, which saw [[Tim Berners-Lee]] (credited with inventing the World Wide Web), [[Susan Greenfield, Baroness Greenfield|Susan Greenfield]], [[Bill Thompson (technology writer)|Bill Thompson]] and [[Chris Anderson (writer)|Chris Anderson]] discuss the World Wide Web.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/technology/2009/07/the_web_at_20.html|title=The Web at 20|last=Cellan-Jones|first=Rory|authorlink=Rory Cellan-Jones|date=10 July 2009|work=dot.Life|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} The production team took a different approach to the development of the series, described by series producer [[Russell Barnes]] as "radical" and "open-source": "We don't just want to observe bloggers from on high; we want to blog ourselves and get feedback and comment on our ideas."{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8144570.stm|title=Charting the Digital Revolution|last=Barnes|first=Russell|date=10 July 2009|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} He described the four phases the production would take; firstly conducting interviews and inviting comments from users on the programme's blog, the second would see [[Dailies|rushes]] released for others to re-use under a permissive license, thirdly, web users would be engaged, working with the [[Web Science Research Initiative]], and the fourth would be an online, interactive version of the series available after it has finished. The programme team interviewed a number of people who have played a part in the development of the web, including its inventor [[Tim Berners-Lee|Sir Tim Berners-Lee]] and founders of notable brands; [[Bill Gates]] ([[Microsoft]]), [[Steve Wozniak]] ([[Apple Inc.|Apple]]), [[Chad Hurley]] ([[YouTube]]), [[Jimmy Wales]] ([[Wikipedia]]), [[Stewart Brand]] ([[The WELL]]), [[Biz Stone]] and [[Evan Williams (Internet entrepreneur)|Evan Williams]] ([[Twitter]]), [[Peter Thiel]] ([[PayPal]]) and [[Martha Lane Fox]] ([[lastminute.com]]). Academics, including [[Terry Winograd]], [[Sherry Turkle]], [[A. C. Grayling]], [[David Runciman]], [[Ross J. Anderson (professor)|Ross Anderson]] and [[Nigel Shadbolt]], commentators, including [[David Weinberger]], [[Lee Siegel (cultural critic)|Lee Siegel]], [[Douglas Rushkoff]], [[Andrew Keen]] and [[Stephen Fry]], and [[President of Estonia|Estonian President]] [[Toomas Hendrik Ilves|Toomas Ilves]] were also interviewed. Footage of the interviews was also made available on the programme's website.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/virtualrevolution/interviews.shtml|title=Interviewees clips|work=The Virtual Revolution website|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} In October 2009 and while being interviewed for the series, Stephen Fry made a request on [[Twitter]] for people to suggest names for the series, with the final decision being made by the BBC.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/digitalrevolution/2009/10/inspiration-wanted-help-us-nam.shtml|title=Inspiration wanted: help us name the series #bbcnamestorm|last=Biddle|first=Dan|date= 6 October 2009|work=The Virtual Revolution blog|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} The chosen title, ''The Virtual Revolution'', is described by the producers as "a mashup between us and you".{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/virtualrevolution/about.shtml|title=About ''The Virtual Revolution''|work=The Virtual Revolution website|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} ==Episodes== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="background: #ffffff; width: 100%;" |- ! style="background: #bfe0bf;" | # ! style="background: #bfe0bf;" | Title ! style="background: #bfe0bf;" | Directed by ! style="background: #bfe0bf;" | Original airdate ! style="background: #bfe0bf;" | Viewers (overnight estimates) |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 1 |Title = The Great Levelling? |DirectedBy = Philip Smith |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2010|1|30|df=y}} |Aux4 = 1.2 million{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/feb/01/tv-ratings-harry-hill-tv-burp|title=TV ratings: ''Harry Hill's TV Burp'' throws up 6m-plus audience for ITV1|last=Conlan|first=Tara|date=1 February 2010|work=[[guardian.co.uk]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=2 February 2010}} |ShortSummary = The first programme examines the idea of the [[World Wide Web]] as a "great leveller", and how this has shaped the development of the web. Looking at the web as an empowering tool and the access provided to knowledge, Krotoski visits Einar Kvaran, contributor to the online encyclopaedia [[Wikipedia]]. To understand how the web gave rise to Wikipedia, she looks at early online community [[The WELL]], which flourished from the counter-culture and libertarianism of the 1960s, speaking to founder [[Stewart Brand]] and [[John Perry Barlow]], who spoke up for online freedom. [[Al Gore]] speaks about blogs and expressing ideas, and Krotoski visits Ory Okolloh, founder of [[Ushahidi]], which gave people a voice following the unrest after the [[Kenyan presidential election, 2007|2007 Kenyan elections]]. She then talks with [[Tim Berners-Lee|Sir Tim Berners-Lee]] about inventing the World Wide Web while he was at [[CERN]] in the 1980s. [[Kenya]]n farmer Kudjo Agbevi discusses empowerment, and Berners-Lee, Barlow and [[Andrew Keen]] speak about the lack of a controlling authority and hierarchy. Krotoski then examines the conflict between freedom/collaboration and making a profit, speaking to [[Microsoft]] founder [[Bill Gates]] and [[Charles Leadbeater]]. [[Shawn Fanning]] then talks about the beginnings of [[Napster]], challenging traditional business models. [[YouTube]] founder [[Chad Hurley]] talks about [[user-generated content]] and rapper [[Master Shortie]] tells Krotoski about using the web as a promotional tool. [[Arianna Huffington]] of [[The Huffington Post]] talk about combining old and new media, Keen talks about hierarchy and Berners-Lee warns of central control. Krotoski speaks to [[Jimmy Wales]] of Wikipedia about the community structure and to conclude, contributors talk about hierarchy. Other contributors include [[Lee Siegel (cultural critic)|Lee Siegel]], [[Steve Wozniak]] and [[Stephen Fry]]. |LineColor = bfe0bf }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 2 |Title = Enemy of the State? |DirectedBy = Francis Hanly |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2010|2|6|df=y}} |Aux4 = |ShortSummary = Krotoski explores how the web affects [[politics]] and the struggle for [[Power (philosophy)|power]] in both [[Democracy|democratic]] and [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] states; and also how the internet has inspired [[freedom of speech]] via [[social networking sites]] such as [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]]. Krotoski also interviews [[Austin Heap]] in relation to a piece of software called '[[Haystack (software)|Haystack]]', an anti-censorship tool for use against the authorities in Iran, being developed by Austin Heap at the time. Krotoski looks at the history of Twitter, and how in the [[2009 Iranian presidential election]] aftermath, it helped civilians send information about [[2009 Iranian election protests|the protests]] to the rest of the world. She then speaks to [[Biz Stone]] and [[Evan Williams (Internet entrepreneur)|Evan Williams]] about the use of Twitter. She then looks at what the [[internet]] was originally designed for, and goes to [[DARPA|Advanced Research Projects Agency]] who designed [[ARPANET]]. Krotoski talks to [[Vint Cerf]], who, along with [[Bob Kahn]], invented internet protocols and [[packet switching]]. Includes interviews with [[Al Gore]], [[Jeff Bezos]], [[Sir Tim Berners-Lee]], [[Clay Shirky]], [[Stephen Fry]], Ishtiaq Hussain, [[Martha Lane Fox]], [[Paul Meijer]] and [[Persiankiwi|oxfordgirl]]. |LineColor = bfe0bf }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 3 |Title = The Cost of Free |DirectedBy = Dan Kendall |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2010|2|13|df=y}} |Aux4 = }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 4 |Title = Homo Interneticus? |DirectedBy = Molly Milton |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2010|2|20|df=y}} |Aux4 = 1.3 Million }} |} ==Reception== Overnight estimates indicated that 1.2 million people watched the first episode, a 5% audience share. In reviewing the first episode, [[Tom Sutcliffe (broadcaster)|Tom Sutcliffe]] in ''[[The Independent]]'', "glad" the programme contained the "odd sceptic too", said Krotoski was a "fine presenter" that the series was both "premature and overdue":
Premature because when you're in the middle of a forest fire you can have no sensible idea of how it will eventually burn out. Overdue, because the flames have been raging for 15 years now and it's excellent that the BBC is at last sticking a dampened finger in the air to see which direction the wind is blowing.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/the-weekends-television-mo-sun-channel-4brthe-virtual-revolution-sat-bbc2-1884958.html|title= The Weekend's Television: ''Mo'', Sun, Channel 4; ''The Virtual Revolution'', Sat, BBC2|last=Sutcliffe|first=Tom|date=1 February 2010|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}}
For ''[[The Times]]'', Andrew Billen gave the first episode three out of five, saying that Krotoski "offered paradox and dialectic before reaching her bland conclusion that the web was constantly re-inventing itself".{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article7008730.ece|title=Weekend TV|last=Billen|first=Andrew|date=1 February 2010|work=[[The Times]]|publisher=[[News International]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} ''[[The Guardian]]'''s [[Tim Dowling]] said that the first episode "made a better fist of it than most" and that "the contributors struck a nice balance between big name cheerleaders and glowering dissenters". He described Krotoski as "convincingly authoritative" but found that "the big picture was sometimes hard to hold in your head" and "the term 'empowering tool' was deployed frequently but without enlightenment".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2010/jan/31/mo-virtual-revolution-tv-review|title=''Mo''; ''The Virtual Revolution''|last=Dowling|first=Tim|authorlink=Tim Dowling|date=31 January 2010|work=[[guardian.co.uk]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} Ryan Lambie for Den of Geek said that "the phrases 'empowering tool' and 'ultimate leveller' are repeated far too many times" and that "the programme's makers apparently assume that the average viewer has never seen or used the Internet in their life", but felt Krotoski was "engaging and enthusiastic" as host, however "her constant presence in every other shot is strangely distracting".{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/television/408109/the_virtual_revolution_episode_one_review.html|title=''The Virtual Revolution'' episode one review|last=Lambie|first=Ryan|date=1 February 2010|work=Den of Geek|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]|accessdate=3 February 2010}} ''[[The Scotsman]]'''s Paul Whitelaw, who also said the camera was "fixated on Krotoski", felt the first programme was a "disjointed essay which proved fascinating when focusing on the origins of the web, but less so when dealing with more recent and familiar developments".{{cite news|url=http://living.scotsman.com/tvradio/TV-review-The-Virtual-Revolution.6029955.jp|title=TV review: ''The Virtual Revolution'' | ''Seven Ages of Britain''|last=Whitelaw|first=Paul|date=1 February 2010|work=[[The Scotsman]]|publisher=[[Johnston Press]]|accessdate=3 February 2010|location=[[Edinburgh]]}} The series won the 2010 Digital Emmy for Best Digital Program: Non-Fiction{{cite web|url=http://www.itvt.com/story/6632/winners-2010-international-digital-emmy-awards-announced|title=Winners of the 2010 International Digital Emmy Awards Announced|accessdate=14 April 2010}} and the 2010 BAFTA television award for New Media.{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/television/television-awards-nominations-in-2010,1095,BA.html|title=BAFTA Television Awards Winners in 2010|accessdate=13 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823025619/http://www.bafta.org/awards/television/television-awards-nominations-in-2010,1095,BA.html|archivedate=23 August 2010|df=dmy-all}} ==See also== *''[[Hyperland]]'' – 1990 [[BBC]] documentary written and presented by [[Douglas Adams]], which foreshadowed many aspects of the modern internet. * ''[[Google and the World Brain]]'', 2013 BBC-assisted documentary about Google's efforts on scanning all the books in the world ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/virtualrevolution/licences/digitalrevolution_licence.shtml | title = Digital Revolution full license | accessdate = 2014-03-06 }} }} ==External links== * {{BBC programme}} * [http://www.open2.net/digitalrevolution/index.html ''The Virtual Revolution''] at the [[Open University]] * {{IMDb title|id=1594955|title=The Virtual Revolution}} * [https://www.theguardian.com/technology/video/2010/mar/21/austin-heap-haystacks A video interview of Austin Heap by Aleks Krotoski] at [[The Guardian|The Guardian Online]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Virtual Revolution, The}} [[Category:BBC television documentaries]] [[Category:Documentary films about the Internet]] [[Category:2010s British television series]] [[Category:Information Age]] [[Category:2010 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2010 British television programme endings]] [[Category:English-language television programs]]

revision.comment: /* top */clean up, replaced: Cambridge, Mass. → Cambridge, Massachusetts using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text: A timeline of events related to [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] [[information theory]], [[File:Orange pog.svg|12px]] [[quantum information theory]] and [[statistical physics]], [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] [[data compression]], [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] [[error correcting code]]s and related subjects. * 1872 [[File:Orange pog.svg|12px]] – [[Ludwig Boltzmann]] presents his [[H-theorem]], and with it the formula Σ''p''i log ''p''i for the entropy of a single gas particle * 1878 [[File:Orange pog.svg|12px]] – [[J. Willard Gibbs]] defines the [[Gibbs entropy]]: the probabilities in the entropy formula are now taken as probabilities of the state of the ''whole'' system * 1924 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Harry Nyquist]] discusses quantifying "intelligence" and the speed at which it can be transmitted by a communication system * 1927 [[File:Orange pog.svg|12px]] – [[John von Neumann]] defines the [[von Neumann entropy]], extending the Gibbs entropy to quantum mechanics * 1928 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Ralph Hartley]] introduces [[Hartley information]] as the logarithm of the number of possible messages, with information being communicated when the receiver can distinguish one sequence of symbols from any other (regardless of any associated meaning) * 1929 [[File:Orange pog.svg|12px]] – [[Leó Szilárd]] analyses [[Maxwell's Demon]], showing how a [[Szilard engine]] can sometimes transform information into the extraction of useful work * 1940 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Alan Turing]] introduces the [[deciban]] as a measure of information inferred about the German [[Enigma machine]] cypher settings by the [[Banburismus]] process * 1944 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Claude Shannon]]'s theory of information is substantially complete * 1947 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Richard W. Hamming]] invents [[Hamming code]]s for error detection and correction (to protect patent rights, the result is not published until 1950) * 1948 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Claude E. Shannon]] publishes ''[[A Mathematical Theory of Communication]]'' * 1949 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Claude E. Shannon]] publishes ''Communication in the Presence of Noise'' – [[Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem]] and [[Shannon–Hartley law]] * 1949 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Claude E. Shannon]]'s ''[[Communication Theory of Secrecy Systems]]'' is declassified * 1949 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – [[Robert M. Fano]] publishes ''Transmission of Information''. M.I.T. Press, Cambridge, Massachusetts – [[Shannon–Fano coding]] * 1949 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – Leon G. Kraft discovers [[Kraft's inequality]], which shows the limits of [[prefix codes]] * 1949 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Marcel J. E. Golay]] introduces [[Golay code (disambiguation)|Golay code]]s for [[forward error correction]] * 1951 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Solomon Kullback]] and [[Richard Leibler]] introduce the [[Kullback–Leibler divergence]] * 1951 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – [[David A. Huffman]] invents [[Huffman encoding]], a method of finding optimal [[prefix codes]] for [[lossless]] [[data compression]] * 1953 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – [[August Albert Sardinas]] and George W. Patterson devise the [[Sardinas–Patterson algorithm]], a procedure to decide whether a given [[variable-length code]] is uniquely decodable * 1954 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Irving S. Reed]] and [[David E. Muller]] propose [[Reed–Muller code]]s * 1955 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Peter Elias]] introduces [[convolutional code]]s * 1957 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Eugene Prange]] first discusses [[cyclic code]]s * 1959 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Alexis Hocquenghem]], and independently the next year [[Raj Chandra Bose]] and [[Dwijendra Kumar Ray-Chaudhuri]], discover [[BCH code]]s * 1960 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Irving S. Reed]] and [[Gustave Solomon]] propose [[Reed–Solomon code]]s * 1962 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Robert G. Gallager]] proposes [[low-density parity-check code]]s; they are unused for 30 years due to technical limitations * 1965 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Dave Forney]] discusses [[concatenated code]]s * 1967 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Andrew Viterbi]] reveals the [[Viterbi algorithm]], making decoding of convolutional codes practicable * 1968 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Elwyn Berlekamp]] invents the [[Berlekamp–Massey algorithm]]; its application to decoding BCH and Reed–Solomon codes is pointed out by [[James Lee Massey|James L. Massey]] the following year * 1968 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[Chris Wallace (computer scientist)|Chris Wallace]] and David M. Boulton publish the first of many papers on [[Minimum Message Length]] ([[Minimum Message Length|MML]]) statistical and inductive inference * 1970 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Valerii Denisovich Goppa]] introduces [[Goppa code]]s * 1972 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Jørn Justesen]] proposes [[Justesen code]]s, an improvement of Reed–Solomon codes * 1973 [[File:Red pog.svg|12px]] – [[David Slepian]] and [[Jack Keil Wolf|Jack Wolf]] discover and prove the [[Slepian–Wolf coding]] limits for distributed [[source coding]]{{cite journal |last1=Slepian |first1=David S. |author1link=David Slepian |last2=Wolf |first2=Jack K. |author2link=Jack Wolf |date=July 1973 |title=Noiseless coding of correlated information sources |url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/articleDetails.jsp?reload=true&arnumber=1055037 |publisher=[[IEEE]] |journal=[[IEEE Transactions on Information Theory]] |volume=19 |issue=4 |issn=0018-9448 |doi=10.1109/TIT.1973.1055037 |pages=471–480}} * 1976 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Gottfried Ungerboeck]] gives the first paper on [[trellis modulation]]; a more detailed exposition in 1982 leads to a raising of analogue modem [[Plain old telephone service|POTS]] speeds from 9.6 kbit/s to 33.6 kbit/s * 1976 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – Richard Pasco and [[Jorma J. Rissanen]] develop effective [[arithmetic coding]] techniques * 1977 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – [[Abraham Lempel]] and [[Jacob Ziv]] develop Lempel–Ziv compression ([[LZ77]]) * 1989 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – [[Phil Katz]] publishes [[ZIP (file format)|the .zip format]] including [[DEFLATE]] (LZ77 + Huffman coding); later to become the most widely used archive container * 1993 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Claude Berrou]], [[Alain Glavieux]] and [[Punya Thitimajshima]] introduce [[Turbo code]]s * 1994 [[File:Green pog.svg|12px]] – [[Michael Burrows]] and [[David Wheeler (computer scientist)|David Wheeler]] publish the [[Burrows–Wheeler transform]], later to find use in [[bzip2]] * 1995 [[File:Orange pog.svg|12px]] – [[Benjamin Schumacher]] coins the term [[qubit]] and proves the [[quantum noiseless coding theorem]] * 2008 [[File:Purple pog.svg|12px]] – [[Erdal Arıkan]] introduces [[Polar code (coding theory)|polar codes]], the first practical construction of codes that achieves capacity for a wide array of channels ==References== {{Reflist|1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Timeline Of Information Theory}} [[Category:Science timelines|Information theory]] [[Category:Information theory]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Missing information|the movement itself|date=January 2010}} {{too few opinions|date=September 2010}} {{refimprove|date=August 2015}} {{more footnotes|date=August 2015}} }}
{{Progressivism}} '''Transnational progressivism''' is a term [[Neologism|coined]] by [[Hudson Institute]] Fellow [[John Fonte]] in 2001 to describe an [[ideology]] which endorses a concept of postnational [[global citizen]]ship and promotes the authority of international institutions over the sovereignty of individual nation-states.<ref name="Fonte May 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2008"/>
==Overview==
Fonte argued that the core beliefs of this view include:
*Advocating the goals of an identity group rather than individual: "The key political unit is not the individual citizen...but the ascriptive group (racial, ethnic, or gender) into which one is born."<ref name="Fonte May 2002">John Fonte, [http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/archives_roll/2002_04-06/fonte_ideological/fonte_ideological.html "The Ideological War Within the West,"] ''Watch on the West'', Volume 3, Number 6, May 2002</ref><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002">John Fonte, [http://www.hudson.org/files/publications/transnational_progressivism.pdf "Liberal Democracy vs. Transnational Progressivism: The Future of the Ideological Civil War Within the West,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202204141/http://www.hudson.org/files/publications/transnational_progressivism.pdf |date=2008-12-02 }} ''Orbis'', Summer 2002</ref><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2008">John Fonte, [http://www.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=31179 "Global Governance vs. the Liberal Democratic Nation-State,"] ''Front Page Magazine'', June 04, 2008</ref> *An oppressor/victim dichotomy: "Transnational ideologists have incorporated the essentially [[Hegel]]ian [[Marxist]] "privileged vs. marginalized" dichotomy," with "immigrant groups designated as victims."<ref name="Fonte May 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2008"/> *Proportional representation by group: "Transnational progressivism assumes that "victim" groups should be represented in all professions roughly proportionate to their percentage of the population. If not, there is a problem of "underrepresentation."<ref name="Fonte May 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2008"/> *Change in institutional values: "the distinct worldviews of ethnic, gender, and linguistic minorities must be represented" within dominant social and political institutions.<ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2008"/> *Change in the [[cultural assimilation|assimilation]] [[paradigm]]: "The traditional paradigm based on the assimilation of immigrants into an existing American civic culture is obsolete and must be changed to a framework that promotes "diversity," defined as group proportionalism."<ref name="Fonte May 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2008"/> *Redefinition of democracy: "Changing the system of majority rule among equal citizens to one of power sharing among ethnic groups composed of both citizens and non-citizens."<ref name="Fonte May 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002"/><ref name="Fonte Orbis 2008"/> *Deconstruction of Western national narratives and national symbols in favor of post-modern multiculturalist views.<ref name="Fonte Orbis 2002"/>
==Transnational progressivism in fiction== In [[John Ringo]]'s [[military science fiction]] series [[Legacy of the Aldenata]], the Aldenata are described disparagingly as "galactic tranzis".
[[Tom Kratman]] references tranzi in "Caliphate", a near future science fiction novel. In the afterword, which is not fiction, he describes how the tranzi's policy of appeasement and inertia cause the subjection of Europe to Islamic control.
==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Cosmopolitanism]] *[[Democratic peace theory]] *[[European Union]] *[[Federal World Government]] *[[Federalism]] *[[Global governance]] *[[International Court of Justice]] *[[Internationalism (politics)]] *[[League of Nations]] *[[Multilateralism]] *[[National sovereignty]] *[[New world order (politics)]] *[[Presidentialism]] *[[Supranationalism]] *[[Transnationalism]] *[[United Nations]] *[[World government]] *[[World political party]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/archives_roll/2002_04-06/fonte_ideological/fonte_ideological.html Text of Fonte article] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060104192734/http://www.educationnext.org/20042/38.html Analysis of Transnational progressivism] *[https://erbosoft.com/ussclueless/cd_log_entries/2003/10/Democraticcontradictions.htm Blogger Stephen Den Beste summary of Transnational Progressivism] *[http://www.newcriterion.com/archive/23/oct04/osull.htm Gulliver's travails] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081202204141/http://www.hudson.org/files/publications/transnational_progressivism.pdf Liberal Democracy vs. Transnational Progressivism: The Future of the Ideological Civil War Within the West (pdf of article as it appeared in Orbis, Summer issue of 2002)]

revision.text:
{{About|the twentieth-century in theatre|the theatre in Cincinnati, Ohio|Twentieth Century Theatre}} {{Refimprove|auto=yes|date=February 2012}}
'''Twentieth-century theatre''' describes a period of great change within the [[Theatre|theatrical]] [[culture]] of the 20th century, mainly in [[Europe]] and [[North America]]. There was a widespread challenge to long-established rules surrounding theatrical representation; resulting in the development of many new forms of theatre, including [[modernism]], [[Expressionism (theatre)|Expressionism]], [[Impressionism]], [[political theatre]] and other forms of [[Experimental theatre]], as well as the continuing development of already established theatrical forms like [[Naturalism (theatre)|naturalism]] and [[Realism (theatre)|realism]].
Throughout the century, the artistic reputation of theatre improved after being derided throughout the 19th century. However, the growth of other media, especially [[History of film|film]], has resulted in a diminished role within the culture at large. In light of this change, theatrical artists have been forced to seek new ways to engage with society. The various answers offered in response to this have prompted the transformations that make up its modern history.<ref>Richard Drain, Preface, ''Twentieth-Century Theatre: A Sourcebook," Taylor & Francis, 1995.</ref>
Developments in areas like [[Gender studies|Gender theory]] and [[Postmodernism|postmodern philosophy]] identified and created subjects for the theatre to explore. These sometimes explicitly meta-theatrical performances were meant to confront the audience's perceptions and assumptions in order to raise questions about their society. These challenging and influential plays characterized much of the final two decades of the 20th-century.
Although largely developing in [[Europe]] and [[North America]] through the beginning of the century, the next 50 years saw an embrace of non-Western theatrical forms. Influenced by the dismantling of empires and the continuing development of [[Post-colonialism|post-colonial]] theory, many new artists utilized elements of their own [[culture]]s and [[Society|societies]] to create a diversified theatre.
==Realism== [[File:MAT original company 1899.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The original company of the Moscow Art Theatre in 1899]]
Realism focuses on the attempt to represent subject matter truthfully, without artificiality and avoiding artistic conventions or implausible, exotic and supernatural elements. For many theatre artists throughout the century, realism was meant to direct attention to the social and psychological problems of ordinary life.
Influenced by the ideas of [[Sigmund Freud]], [[Charles Darwin]] and others, many artists began to find a [[psychological]] approach to theatre that emphasized the inner dimensions of the characters onstage. This was carried out both on the stage in [[acting]] styles, in [[Playwright|play writing]] and in [[Scenic design|theatrical design]]. Beginning with the work Russian playwrights [[Ivan Turgenev]], [[Alexander Ostrovsky]] and [[Leo Tolstoy]] and continued by [[Emile Zola]] in France and [[Henrik Ibsen]] in Norway in the late [[Nineteenth century theatre|19th Century]], realism came to dominate most of the theatrical culture of the 20th century in Britain and North America.
===Russia===
In Russia, the movement towards realism began earlier than anywhere else in the world. Building on the work of earlier pioneers, [[Constantin Stanislavski]] and [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]] founded the [[Moscow Art Theatre]] in 1898, wanting to reform a Russian theatre dominated by [[melodrama]] to one in which high-quality art was available to the general public. In perhaps the most important theatrical meeting of the 20th century, the two met for an epic 18-hours, from 2 pm to 8 am the next morning, and laid the foundation for one of the most influential companies of the century.<ref>Benedetti, Jean. 1991. The Moscow Art Theatre Letters. New York: Routledge.</ref> Together they would forge a professional company with an ensemble ethos that discouraged individual vanity, selecting actors from Nemirovich's class at the Philharmonic school and Stanislavsky's amateur Society of Art and Literature group, along with other professional actors; they would create a realistic theatre of international renown, with popular prices for seats, whose organically [[Gesamtkunstwerk|unified aesthetic]] would bring together the techniques of the [[Meiningen Ensemble]] and those of [[André Antoine]]'s [[Théâtre Libre]] (which Stanislavsky had seen during trips to Paris).<ref>Benedetti (1989, 18) and (1999, 61–62)</ref>
On December 29, 1898, the theatre opened [[Anton Chekhov]]'s [[Moscow Art Theatre production of The Seagull|The Seagull]] with Stanislavski himself playing the role of Trigorin and [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as Treplev in "one of the greatest events in the history of Russian theatre and one of the greatest developments in the history of world drama."<ref>Rudnitsky (1981, 8) and Benedetti (1999, 85)</ref> Nemirovich described the applause, which came after a prolonged silence, as bursting from the audience like a [[dam]] breaking and the production received unanimous praise from the press.<ref name="b86">Benedetti (1999, 86).</ref> Later analysts attribute the production's success to the fidelity of its delicate representation of everyday life, its intimate, ensemble playing, and the resonance of its mood of despondent uncertainty with the psychological disposition of the Russian intelligentsia of the time.<ref>Braun (1981, 64).</ref> Productions of Ibsen, [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]], and Chekhov's [[Uncle Vanya]], [[The Cherry Orchard]] and [[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]] were also very successful in the early days of the company.
After the success of the Moscow Art Theatre, Stanislavski set out to create a [[Stanislavski's system|unified system of acting]] that would train actors and actresses to create believable characterizations for their performances. Developed mainly between 1911 and 1916 and revised throughout his life, the approach was partly based on the concept of emotional memory for which an actor focuses internally to portray a character's emotions onstage. Areas of study include concentration, voice, physical skills, emotion memory, observation, and dramatic analysis. The Stanislavsky system was widely practiced in the Soviet Union and in the United States, where experiments in its use began in the 1920s and continued in many schools and professional workshops.
In the early part of the 20th century, Russia experienced a cultural [[Russian literature#Silver Age|Silver Age]] and the theatre was no exception. By 1916, the total number of producing theatres in Moscow alone totaled close to 200. These year-round and seasonal theatres produced mainly farces, comedies, vaudevilles and even melodramas, but there were also a significant number of theatres offering realistic or [[naturalism (theatre)|naturalistic]] theatre. These included [[Aleksey Suvorin]]'s [[Maly Theatre (Moscow)|Maly Theatre]] and the Moscow Dramatic Theatre (1914–19). While there were a number of actress-managers in [[St. Petersburg]] and [[Moscow]] like [[Vera Komissarzhevskaya]] and [[Ida Rubinstein]], the course of Russian theatre in the Silver Age was largely dominated by men.<ref>Golub, 278-282.</ref>
After the [[First World War]] and the [[Russian Revolution]], many theatre artists left Russia for other countries, including [[Georges Pitoëff]] to France, [[Theodore Komisarjevsky]] to Britain, and, famously, [[Michael Chekhov|Mikhael Chekhov]] to the United States, exporting the Stanislavski system and contributing to the development of a 'director's theatre' in the post-war world.<ref>Esslin, 379</ref>
[[File:Eugene O'Neill 1936.jpg|thumb|left|[[Eugene O'Neill]] had a huge influence on the development of modern American drama.]]
===United States===
In the United States, [[William Vaughn Moody]]'s plays ''The Great Divide'' (1906) and ''The Faith Healer'' (1909) pointed the way to a more realistic American drama in their emphasis on the emotional conflicts that lie at the heart of contemporary social conflicts. Other key playwrights signaling the move to realism in the beginning of the century include [[Edward Sheldon]], [[Charles Rann Kennedy]] and [[Rachel Crothers]]. Onstage, the American theatre was dominated by the [[Barrymore family]]: [[Lionel Barrymore]], [[Ethel Barrymore]] (the "First Lady of American Theater") and [[John Barrymore]] ("... the most influential and idolized actor of his day."). They were so popular that a play was even written about them: [[The Royal Family (play)|The Royal Family]] by [[George S. Kaufman]] and [[Edna Ferber]], a parody of the Barrymores, with particular aim taken at John and Ethel Barrymore.
Through the early century, no American dramatist had as much influence on the development of drama as [[Eugene O'Neill]]. Born into the theatre from a young age, he spent much of his youth on trains and backstage at theatres, before developing his talent with the [[Provincetown Players]] in New York City. Between 1916 and 1920, he wrote several plays for the company before debuting his first critical hit ''[[Beyond the Horizon (play)|Beyond the Horizon]]'' in 1920, which went on to win the [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]]. He followed that with critical and commercial successes, including ''[[The Emperor Jones]]'', ''[[Anna Christie]]'' (Pulitzer Prize 1922), ''[[Desire Under the Elms]]'' (1924), ''[[Strange Interlude]]'' (Pulitzer Prize 1928), ''[[Mourning Becomes Electra]]'' (1931), ''[[The Iceman Cometh]]'' (1939) and his only well-known comedy, ''[[Ah, Wilderness!]]''. After his death, his magnum opus and masterwork ''[[Long Day's Journey into Night]]'' was published and is often regarded to be one of the finest American plays of the 20th century.
The economic crisis of the [[Great Depression]] led to the creation of the [[Federal Theatre Project]] (1935–39), a [[New Deal]] program which funded theatre and other live artistic performances throughout the country. National director [[Hallie Flanagan]] shaped the project into a federation of regional theatres that created relevant art, encouraged experimentation and made it possible for millions of Americans to see theatre for the first time. The project directly employed 15,000 men and women and played 1,200 productions to nearly 30 million people in 200 theatres nationwide, with 65% being presented free of charge, at a total cost of $46 million.<ref name="Arena">{{cite book |last=Flanagan |first=Hallie |authorlink=Hallie Flanagan |date=1965 |title=Arena: The History of the Federal Theatre |url= |location=New York |publisher=Benjamin Blom, reprint edition [1940] |oclc=855945294}}</ref>
Key figures of the early century include [[George S. Kaufman]], [[George Kelly (playwright)|George Kelly]], [[Langston Hughes]], [[S. N. Behrman]], [[Sidney Howard]], [[Robert E. Sherwood]], and a set of playwrights who followed O'Neill's path of philosophical searching, [[Philip Barry]], [[Thornton Wilder]] and [[William Saroyan]].
==Modernism== Modernism was a predominantly European movement that developed as a self-conscious break from traditional art forms. It represents a significant shift in cultural sensibilities, often attributed to the fallout of [[World War I]].<ref>Modris Ekstein, ''Rites of Spring: The Great War and the Birth of the Modern Age,'' Lester & Orpen Dennys, 2002.</ref> At first, the modernist theatre was in large part an attempt to realize the reformed stage on [[Naturalism (theatre)|naturalistic]] principles as advocated by [[Émile Zola]] in the 1880s. However, a simultaneous reaction against naturalism urged the theatre in a much different direction. Owing much to [[symbolism (arts)|symbolism]], the movement attempted to integrate poetry, painting, music, and dance in a harmonious fusion. Both of these seemingly conflicting movements fit under the term 'Modernism'.<ref>Drain 3</ref>
==Political theatre== [[File:Augusto Boal nyc5.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A workshop of [[Augusto Boal]]'s [[Theatre of the Oppressed]] in 2008.]] Political theatre is an attempt to rethink the nature and function of theatre in the light of the dynamics of the society outside it and audience involvement within it. It led to profound and original theories of [[acting]], staging and [[Playwright|playwriting]].<ref>Drain 75.</ref>
==Popular theatre== At the beginning of the 20th century, many viewed theatre as an "all-too-popular affair."<ref>Drain 153</ref> Frequently, the true reformers of the early part of the century called for increasingly smaller theatres, where their techniques could register on a select audience. Still, these same practitioners often dreamed that their art would be a true people's theatre: a theatre for the people. Inspired by an understanding of the [[Greek theatre]] and heavily influenced by [[Nietzsche]], they sought a profound or ecstatic ritual event that involved music and movement, in a space without a [[proscenium arch]]. Later, practitioners like [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] and [[Bertolt Brecht]] would initiate an attempt to bridge the "gulf" between modernism and the people.<ref>Drain 156-157</ref>
===Musical theatre===
In popular [[musical theatre]] there have been different trends and phases of commercial success, including works of the following:
* the great popularity of the British [[Edwardian musical comedies]] (1892-1917), * the advent of the [[Princess Theatre, New York City|Princess Theatre]] musicals in New York (1913-1923), * the emergence of American popular [[musical theatre]], with the works of: **[[Jerome Kern]] (1885-1945); [[Princess Theatre, New York City|Princess Theatre]] musicals, ''[[Ziegfeld Follies]] (1916, 1917), ''[[Show Boat]]'' (1927) ** [[George Gershwin]] (1898-1937) and [[Ira Gershwin]] (1896-1983) ''[[Rhapsody in Blue]]'' (1924), ''[[An American in Paris]]'' (1928), ''[[Porgy and Bess]]'' (1935). **[[Cole Porter]] (1891-1964); [[Paris (1928 musical)|''Paris'']] (1928), ''[[Wake Up and Dream]]'' (1929), ''[[Anything Goes]]'' (1934) **[[Rodgers and Hart]]; [[Richard Rodgers]] (1902-1979) and [[Lorenz Hart]] (1895-1943) ''[[Babes in Arms]]'' (1937), ''[[Pal Joey (musical)|Pal Joey]]'' (1940) **[[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]; [[Richard Rodgers]] (1902-1979) and [[Oscar Hammerstein II]] (1895 – 1960):''[[Oklahoma!]]'' (1943), ''[[Carousel (musical)|Carousel]]'' (1945), ''[[South Pacific (musical)|South Pacific]]'' (1949), ''[[The King and I]]'' (1951) and ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' (1959). *In the second half of the 20th century, new creative talents emerged and attracted large audiences, including: ** [[Stephen Sondheim]] (1930--); ''[[West Side Story]]'' (1957) (lyrics), ''[[A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum]]'' (1962), ''[[A Little Night Music]]'' (1973), ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (musical)|Sweeney Todd]]'' (1979), ''[[Into the Woods]]'' (1987). ** [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] (1948--); ''[[Evita (musical)|Evita]]'' (1978), ''[[Cats (musical)|Cats]]'' (1981), [[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]] (1986) **[[Claude-Michel Schönberg]] (1944--) and [[Alain Boublil]] (1941--); ''[[Les Misérables (musical)]]'' (1980), and ''[[Miss Saigon]]'' (1989)
==Post-modern theatre== Post-modern theatre is a recent phenomenon in world theatre, coming as it does out of the [[postmodern philosophy]] that originated in Europe in the middle of the 20th century. Post-modern theatre emerged as a reaction against modernist theatre. Most post-modern productions are centered around highlighting the fallibility of definite truth, instead encouraging the audience to reach their own individual understanding. Essentially, thus, post-modern theatre raises questions rather than attempting to supply answers.
==Global theatre== At the beginning of the 20th-century, many European audiences were exposed to the "exotic" theatrical world of [[Japanese theatre|Japanese]] and [[Chinese theatre|Chinese]] performances. This led to many Western practitioners interpreting and incorporating these styles into their own theatres: most notably [[Bertolt Brecht]]'s adaptation of [[Chinese opera]] to support his 'Alienation' effect. The influence of the non-western theatre on theatrical culture in the 20th-century has often been crucial to new developments. However, the period during and after the advent of [[Post-colonialism|post-colonial]] theory in the 1960s and 1970s, has led to a tremendous amount of development in theatre practice all over the world. This has created, for the first time, a truly global theatre.<ref>Drain 293</ref>
==Significant figures== Significant figures and some landmark theories and movements of the period include: * [[Constantin Stanislavski]] (1863-1938) and his [[Stanislavski's system|system]]: a "naturalistic" method of drawing on the actor's own emotional memories to convey a character's thoughts and emotions * [[Antonin Artaud]] (1896-1948) and the [[Theatre of Cruelty]]: a plan to force the audience to shed their illusions * [[Bertolt Brecht]] (1898-1956) and [[Epic theatre]]: a reaction against Stanislavski's naturalistic method, Epic theatre makes clear that the audience is watching a play and an artifice * [[Lee Strasberg]] (1901-1982) and [[Method acting]]: which trains actors to draw upon their own emotions and memories, to convincingly portray a part. * [[Jerzy Grotowski]] (1933–1999), who introduced the concept of "poor theatre" * [[Eugenio Barba]], Grotowski's disciple and founder of the [[Odin Theatret]], introducing the concepts of theatrical anthropology * [[Samuel Beckett]] (1906-1989) and [[Theatre of the Absurd]]: in a modern world without meaning or purpose, a play's dialog, plot and characters give up the threads of "logic" or "message". (related to [[Existentialism]]) * [[Hans-Thies Lehmann]]'s theory of [[Postdramatic theatre]]: focused more on effect on the audience than on the original text.
===Nobel laureates=== During the twentieth-century the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] was awarded to the following who were primarily [[Playwright|dramatist]]s:
* 1904 - [[José Echegaray]] — Spanish; ''El gran Galeoto'' * 1910 - [[Paul Heyse]] — German * 1911 - [[Maurice Maeterlinck]] — Belgian * 1912 - [[Gerhart Hauptmann]] — German * 1915 - [[Romain Rolland]] — French * 1922 - [[Jacinto Benavente]] — Spanish * 1925 - [[George Bernard Shaw]] — Irish * 1934 - [[Luigi Pirandello]] — Italian * 1936 - [[Eugene O'Neill]] — American * 1969 - [[Samuel Beckett]] — Irish * 1986 - [[Wole Soyinka]] — Nigerian * 1997 - [[Dario Fo]] — Italian
The 2005 Nobel Prize in Literature was awarded to the Englishman [[Harold Pinter]], most of whose [[Works of Harold Pinter|works]] originated in the twentieth-century.
==See also== * [[Timeline of twentieth-century theatre]] * [[History of theatre]] * [[Nineteenth-century theatre]] * [[Experimental theatre|Avant-garde theatre]] * [[Musical theatre]]
